If I could, I would take this game out, buy it dinner, have sex with it and call it the next day. Then we would start going out regularly, we would fall in love eventually. We would become the couple that has their own inside jokes and are always teasing each other and everyone else would be jealous of us. We would get married and have a child (System shock 2, the second best game ever). We would grow old together, on my dead bed as I lie there about to draw my last breath, Fallout 2 looks at me with tears in it's eyes "Thank you for everything, you were always so good to me" and I would take Fallout 2s hand, look it in the eye and say "No, thank YOU" then pass away. number of helpful: 418 of 428 people (98%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												*I have included some tips at the end to help newcomers to the early Fallouts*I remember the hundreds of hours I've spent on the console version of Fallout 3 back in 2011. Fast forward to early 2015, I've decided to try out the older Fallouts, starting with Fallout 2. This being my first "true" RPG experience, all of the info and stats, along with the fact that it was a turn based isometric game, made it look intimidating from the surface, but after some researching, the game starts to look less daunting.Just like the Bethesda Fallouts, the game uses the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system and the familiar stats, along with traits. Fallout 2 really does gives you a lot of options on how you can adjust your character. Naturally, I (stupidly) chose to have a really buff gunman with perception and agility as my dump stats. I went through the Temple of Trials (the tutorial dungeon) and got demolished. My stats made playing through the game a nightmare. See, unlike Fallout 3, the stats you choose matter a great deal more. Some of stats in Fallout 2 function the same as Fallout 3 (Strength judges carry weight and ability to use weapons, Intelligence increases skill points, Endurance increases HP and resistance, Agility affects Action Ponts, Luck increases stats slightly and influences random encounters). However, some act differently. Perception affects how acurate you are at longer ranges, every single action requires Action Points meaning that high Agility builds are better for combat, Charisma affects the number of companions you can have, and low Intelligence can effectively deny you from a large amount of quests and activities.With this information, I remade my character and went back into the Temple of Trials. It must be said, however, that the Temple is a very poor representation of the game. The game forces you to use melee and barely gives you enough healing items to get past the darn thing if you don't use hit and run tactics with high agility. Fallout 2 gives you no information regarding mechanics, and it's clear that the devs were forced to phone in a tutorial segment (if you can call it that).Fortunately, the game starts to show its magic after you exit the Temple and rejoin the villagers of Arroyo, the home of the decendants of the protagonist of the first Fallout. The village is dying and you are tasked to gind the G.E.C.K, a device that can help bring life back to the village. From there, you find a multitude of interesting characters and locations, such as New Reno and its many gangs, to the Broken Hills with its super mutants. Although there is a small amount of quests compared to the later games, the quality of the dialogue and the world you are thrown into makes it easy to forgive. The game also includes some returning characters from the first Fallout, which give some background to the protagonist and the events of the first game. Unfortunately, the humor of this game is something that may not be appealing to some, however. Fallout 2 does include many pop culture references and fourth wall breaks, which does get tiring admittedly.Combat in this game is very enjoyable and has a satisfying punch to it, with gory animations accompanying sounds of limbs being blown off. The amount of weapons in this game is fairly reasonable, but this is mainly towards the end where you have gained large amounts of money and can handle the tougher enemies with better loot.Overall, Fallout 2 is a real classic of a game. It may be hard to adjust as a newcomer, but the game is very much worth it.*Some tips*- You have four types of cursors in the game (switch by using M2), a yellow arrow (click on items to interact, hold M1 to get a list of interactions), a red hexagon (decides where you go), a hand (decides what you pick up in the inventory screen), and a red crosshair (decides what you shoot, only accessable when you are in combat).- You can break wooden doors by using melee on them or using a grenade.- To use Skilldex skills, click on the skilldex button, choose the skill and then the item you want to use the skill on.Examples: Click on Doctor and yourself to heal. Click on Lockpick and a door to lockpick. Click on Steal and a person to steal.- Before exiting towns or talking to important characters, save.- To change the action done to a weapon you are holding, press M2 on the weapon box. For guns, this can change them to Single Fire, Aimed, Burst (If the gun has it), or Reload. The green ticks on the side of the weapon represent the ammo level.- When bartering, make sure to get change from transactions. For example, if I bought a gun that costs $1000 and gave a gun that costs $950, I need to bring the vendor's money into the transaction area to get money. In this case, I would ask for $50.- The red button above the inventory button helps switch weapons.- To enter combat with friendlies (or unaware enemies), click on your weapon. To end combat, press the CMBT on the bottom right. To end your turn, press Turn. (Also on the bottom right).- Rest by clicking the Pipboy button and clicking on the yellow button on the top of its menu. This can only be done after finishing the Temple of Trials.-  You can scavenge extra ammo from dead NPCs by using the yellow cursor and choosing the "unload gun" icon (picture of a gun and magazine) from the interation list.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												THIS GAME.THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME.BUYING THIS GAME WAS ONE OF THE WORST MISTAKES I EVER MADE.I started this game up expecting to have a good time, as I did with the other Fallout games. I'd played Fallout 1, and I'd heard from almost everyone that Fallout 2 was FAR superior. I throroughly enjoyed Fallout 1, but my main problem with it was that the game was timed, and practically forced you to rush through it. Because of this, I felt as though my experience with the game was cut short. The main thing I was looking for when I started playing Fallout 2 was a lengthier game that would allow me to explore and progress at my own pace.I got more than I could have ever hoped for.The game started out slow, much like many other RPGs, and frankly, it was a bit boring for the first few hours. But I knew from my previous experiences that Fallout games only get better as you progress. I made it through the first few areas, and started getting a feel for how things worked, finding plenty of new quests, etc. It was becoming rather enjoyable, then I got the car, which would allow me to carry more things, and explore the wasteland with much more ease. It was very exciting, almost like getting my first car all over again. And at that point I was hooked.Everything from that point on is a bit of a blur, I remember traveling from city to city, back and forth, looking for every quest I could possibly find. The process of finding better and better gear for my three companions was addicting, the process of ensuring the prosperity of all the settlements was addicting, the atmosphere is addicting, becoming famous for various reasons across the wasteland was addicting, the fact that the game goes into so much detail and lets you influence the way things play out was addicting. EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS ADDICTING!I couldn't help it, hours and hours of my life were being sucked away, and there was nothing I could to about it except keep playing. IT WAS AMAZING.The final toll was a little over 66 hours for me. And that was all spent on a single playthrough. When I FINALLY beat the game, I felt a feeling of happiness and satisfaction that I haven't felt in YEARS. But most of all, I felt an overwhelming sense of FREEDOM. NO LONGER WAS I SHACKLED BY ITS IMMENSE QUALITY, BY ITS SHEER BEAUTY. I will never play this game for the first time again, that makes me both relieved and depressed. Depressed, because this game is phenomenal, because it is one of the best games I ever played. But relieved, because I will never lose that many hours that quickly ever again.This game is a true gem. It is an incredible, immersive experience even by today's standards, and in fact, shïts all over most modern RPGs.That's the problem, though, this game is TOO GOOD. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME UNLESS YOU HAVE ABSOLUTELY NOTHING TO LOSE.Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna start my evil playthough.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Destroys everything, one of the greatest pieces of art ever created, Fallout 2 is an RPG in which you play a tribesman who is tasked to find and return a device to his village known as the G.E.C.K (which is a piece of technology that is able to revitalize areas of a post-nuclear wasteland, transforming dead, irradiated soil into viable land suitable for farming) to save his people from famine. The plot is subtle and a great break from all the melodramatic, save the universe type♥♥♥♥♥♥most games consist of.Fallout 2, like the first, gives you a large, brutal and unforgiving world to traverse at your own risk, full of genuinely fascinating locations and extremely interesting characters to interact with; from scientists who give mutated scorpions chems to their increase intelligence, talking plants and a highly intelligent and articulate Deathclaw, there are tons of geniusly fantastic, memorable characters to interact with through-out and even though Fallout 2 doesn't always take itself too seriously and is sometimes outright comical the game still portrays a grim, cruel and extremely immersive world like no other.Fallout 2 features some of the finest role playing out there, with tons of meaningful choices and consequences through-out which question your ethics and morality on a far deeper scale than just simply being the good / bad guy. The quests you recieve in Fallout 2 are diverse and often offer multiple ways in which you can complete them, some ways which were not even intended by the developers, there is just so much freedom of choice here that is completely non-existent in 'RPGs' today.The character building is brilliant and has a ton of depth, every little stat directly affects how your game plays out, being highly intelligent with the personality of a brick or being a knucklehead with the charisma of a dictator will deeply affect how NPCs interact with you. There are so many choices to make in character building that have huge, meaningful impacts on the world around you that multiple playthroughs are essential to experience what this masterpiece has to offer.The visuals at first glance may seem bland and out-dated but the art direction is beyond brilliant and is complimented by believable, excellent world design and an insanely thick atmosphere - this doesn't feel like videogame world nor like it was designed to be one, rather an actual post-apocalyptic place.The sound effects are absolutely spot on. The ambient, non-intrusive music through-out is fantastic and adds a lot to the atmosphere and the voiced dialogue is pretty well done. Fallout 2's combat is turn-based and offers a ton of depth, giving you the opportunity to use a tactical approach rather than just mindlessly clicking away like in many of todays so-called RPG's - I do however encounter frustration with not being able to control friendly AI in combat and as a result get shot in the back and watching friendly AI running at an isolated enemy instead of backing up your character who then gets outnumbered and killed is rage-inducing to say the least, these flaws only occur right in the beginning until you get used to pathing and such but rather big flaws non-the-less. Overall Fallout 2, along with Baldur's Gate, Darklands and Planescape Torment are the pinnacle of RPGs in every regard and will probably remain that way until the end of time judging by how far the genre has declined since. You can't call yourself a fan of RPGs until you have experienced these absolute masterpieces, if you're interested in playing Fallout 1 or 2 for the first time and haven't played anything of the sort before I'd advise a lot of patience in the early stages which by judging from some of the negative reviews is too much to ask for some. This is a mandatory experience for anyone who loves videogames, experiences like this simply don't exist anymore.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												If there is a genre of games which I value and play above all others it's first person shooters. Especially competitive MP FPS games like UT, Quake, Counter Strike etc. However every once in a while comes a game that isn't a part of those genres and it's so bloody good that it makes an exception to my preference. This recommendation is for Fallout 1 and 2 which are easily bought in a cheap value pack. Without a doubt they stand as some of the greatest games ever made. Even if they are technologically way behind the times, the concept idea and execution are so well done that this become one of the biggest benchmarks for role playing games in general.These games are simple to explain, it's a free roaming massive quest based role playing game. You start the game with entire world open to you, hardly any restrictions and it's up to you to what happens. There are absurd amount of choices in pretty much everything. Make a character that is a gunslinger, sniper, brute using melee weapons, a silver tonged diplomat, a retard who can only communicate via grunts and hardly understandable shouts,a slaver, evil to the core son of a ♥♥♥♥♥. it's all open to you from start. The character creation portion is extensive, complicated and delightful to how much you can plan out for your game. This is followed numerous ways to solve problems. Almost every problem has multiple solutions, ranging from taking different sides (pleasing or♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off factions), violent approach, diplomatic approach you name it. A person won't help you with something you just take your gun and kill them, then face the consequences. Game is really harsh, anything rash and dumb can easily end up with game over.One huge praise to the choice presented to the player is the adult theme that isn't dumbed down (unlike the more recent Fallout 3 and NV(though NV to less extent)). You can become a porn star, ♥♥♥♥♥ yourself out for services and persuasion, you can kill children and be labeled as a Childkiller. Everything you do reflects your standing in the world and how NPCs look at you.Another big praise is how humor is incorporated into this wacky, grim post apocaliptic world. Expect several monty python references and spoofs.It's seamless and fitting. It's amazing how well such wacky humor incorporated into dark games such as these two.If there are downsides it's that vanilla games are rather buggy. I recommend Killap's unoffical patch/restoration project for fallout 2 and the appropriate patches for fallout 1. Check No Mutants Allowed for patches. Get the resolution patch as well. This way you can upscale the resolution to more modern standard.I could sit here all day and write about the insane amount of cool things to do in this game, but that's better to be experienced in person. Do yourself a favor and if you like RPG games where you are not shoehorned into a path, play these game. They are most certainly some of the best you will ever play.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												While Fallout 2's wacky humor and ridiculous references to things like Monty Python and the Holy Grail might not be for absolutely everyone, it does have a much larger world with much more content than Fallout 1 that is, in my opinion at the very least, of equal quality as it's predecessor. The story shares some similarity to the first game, as you play a tribal descendant of the Vault Dweller, sent out to find a device that will save your dying village of Arroyo from famine and disease.The world, though, feels much larger, showing far more signs of development over the years. Old towns like the LA Boneyard and Junktown have disappeared off the map, replaced with or absorbed into new, more solidly established places like the New California Republic, an evolution of the town of Shady Sands, a San Francisco Chinatown populated by chinese refugees and even New Reno, a city of vice and sin populated by casinos, porn theaters, drug dealers, and gangs of post-nuclear mafiosos all going at each other's throats for control of the city.Mechanically, Fallout 2 tightens up a lot of stuff from the first game. Most immediately noticeable are things like a "Take All" button in container menus, an option to push NPCs out of the way non-violently should they ever block your path, and an overhaul of the companion system, allowing you to get one extra character in your party for every two points of Charisma, with the limit maxing out at five companions for ten Charisma, and the ability to change every companion's strategic options if you don't want them accidentally mowing you down with a Vindicator Minigun.Although Fallout 2 was criticized heavily for it's buggy and rushed state of release, with a large chunk of content never seeing the light of day, it has since received support from modders that fix all of these issues. Most notable are sfall, which makes many engine tweaks and quality of life improvements, and Killapp's Unofficial Patch and Restoration Project, which respectively patch out all the major bugs in the game and fully implement all the cut content seamlessly into the game.All this put together, Fallout 2 is a very large, but tight package with solid mechanics and fun writing, injecting even more personality into the wasteland than the first game. It can miss the mark sometimes, but on the whole it feels like the writers had a fun time, and the game itself is well worth playing even today. Whether or not you're a lover of old-school RPGs, Fallout 2 has a lot on offer, and most of it is pretty superb.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Just over a decade ago, life was simpler and more frivolous, so every fictional discovery was fascinating and entertaining. It was in that simple, mid-teenage life, that I dug Fallout 2 out of a fortunate coincidence. A disc copy of the game, in a modest gaming magazine, to whose cover it was poorly attached. It seemed interesting enough, and with little knowledge of cRPGs or English, I went home and gave it a try. Boy, was I enthralled by this game. A game which would, about ten years later, still be the most cherished piece of gaming I have ever experienced. Fallout 2 ventures deep into the dark territories of humour and morbidity. Not many have the grit for its atmosphere, inauspicious and heavy as it is, its dense soundtrack that evinces feelings of gloomy solitude and decadence; exactly the vibe you have got to be in when playing any Fallout title, for that matter. Back when I first tried it, I would engage in conflicts between the curiosity to explore its narrative and the uneasiness caused by that very atmosphere, even after having previously and briefly tried Planescape: Torment - an equally dense game. Fortunately for me, I got past that.Provided that you can also overcome such uneasiness, you've got an unparallelled RPG challenge ahead of you. Fallout 2, very much like its predecessor, is beautifully written, and cleverly designed in a way that connects your actions to the realities and contextual changes of Northern California as you go. The turn-based combat is typical late-90s cRPG gold. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L role-playing system, a jewel derived from Gurps, offers you that edge of character construction and skill management that makes a bonafide RPG pleasurable. The post-apocalyptic setting and aesthetics, built on the famous premise of the Divergence - the historical fragmentation in which the fictional linearity of the game took a different course from that of our world in the heat of the Cold War, leaving the former with that futuristic-50s style -, renders Fallout's identity unique and typically dark humoured. Its characters are deeply unpredictable and credible, especially the companions, much more mature than those of the previous installment (with all due respect to the likes of Ian and Dogmeat). The game leaves that bitter feeling of longing in the player's mouth should they pass away or have to be left behind for some reason. Each companion adds to the player's enterprise, each has their own story, each has their own passions and motivations. And flaws.Fallout 2 appeals to multiple audiences. Those looking for an RPG; those looking for a post-apocalyptic piece; those looking for a story-driven game; those looking for open-world dynamic narratives; those looking for a demi-horror title; and so forth. While it may not touch some of these categories in depth, it is a game that brings them all to a perfect harmony. Be ready for a challenge, an unforgiving gameplay, but be also ready for enriching rewards that will open your mind to new spheres of role-playing gaming.

												A classic for the ages. When I hear Louis Armstrong on the radio it immediately takes me back to geckos, rad scorpions, and those secure vault tec vaults. The graphics are old but the gameplay and story are great. I feel the content is a bit greater then the orginal fallout making it to be a very long game. Your goal is not only a main quest but also to intervene with the towns and locations you encounter. The ending is the best because it tells you the later fate of all those you've helped or destoryed. One of the best video game endings ever!~update~ I failed to mention this before. Your SPECIAL stats are very important. You will miss a lot of side quests with a low Charisma (people will refuse to talk to you). Other Special stats might play a role at times. Its best to keep them atleast above a 3 or 4. The Gifted trait is a great choice to get 7 extra points to allocate anywhere.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Second volume of the legendary role-playing game about humankind after Doomsday, very thorough both in the battle system and in interactions with the world around player. World with numerous different characters, situations and occasions. And with constant multiplicity of choices for every your step, of course.Now, with the High Res mod which Steam finally added into the launcher. Without that mod, you couldn't play this classic on everything upper to WinXP, which was a bummer really. So glad that Steam finally fixed it…Some of my friends are so purist they think Fallout 2 was a misinterpretation of the first, the-one-and-only, Fallout game. Thanks to Heaven, I'm not one of them. On contrary, I'm enjoying the second game more, for all additional content it have with comparison to the first game. Which was great, but a little straight-forward closer to the end.In the Fallout 2 I've spent dozens and hundreds hours of my time, found so many secrets and easter eggs... It is like a town where you were grown. You may be now a big man from big city, but you'll always remember old shortcuts and hiding places where you were at your childhood...Sure it looks dated, and maybe somewhat clunky at first, but, once you get to know that game better, I’m sure, you’ll love it.My mark for one of the most tempting games of my teens age? 10/10, of course! Yes, it’s dated, yes, it’s much harder and unforgivable for beginners than new-age RPGs… But it’s lovely thing. Like some books, that you want to open again and again, or people you always love to meet.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Before i start the review i would like to give you a overview of what i will speak about in the review Fallout 1 Fallout 2 Fallout 3 Fallout NV and maybe Fallout 4 if i feel i need to Story Fallout 2 is set 80 years after the events of Fallout 1 and you are the grandchild of the 1st games's protaganist the vault dweller you are the chosen one of your village Arroyo tasked with finding a G.E.C.K to help save your village.Gameplay Fallout 2's gameplay may not be appealing to the modern genration but once you become familiar with the combat system and the fact that all quests are unmarked the game becomes excellent Fallout 2 sticks to the formula of the first game you can tell this because the games play virtually the same.For me Fallout 2 was definatley more challenging than Fallout 1 and definatley more challening than the newer Fallout 3 and FNV this brings me onto my next pointWhy i personally think fallout 1,2 and NV are better than 3 and 4Personally i think 2 and NV are the best games in the franchise for me Fallout 2 engrosed me into the deaper lore and decisions of the game along with the backstory. When i comes to the ending of Fallout 3 there is only one major outcome of the game (Im not going to spoil if some of you havent played Fallout 3) and the end credits just talk about what sort of person you were in the game. Whereas in Fallout 1,2 and NV the way you handle quests in different areas and your actions in these areas affect the areas future in a deaper manner. for example Fallout 1,2 and new vegas in the end credit scence you hear things like "Your involvment in this town and how you did this mean the town prospered or the town was quickly eradicated" Wheras in fallout 3 this isnt there. General overview of Fallout 2 Fallout 2 is a timeless classic of the Fallout franchise and for those who consider themselves die hard fans of the fallout series you should get this game also if you do get the game also download the resteration patch from the No mutants allowed forum it adds cut content into the game and fixes bugs and generally makes the game better overallNote: In no way in this review am i hating on Fallout 3 i think Fallout 3 is a brilliant game and i recommend it to anyone but i do not think of it as a Fallout game that stays true to the originals like Fallout New Vegas did Thank you for taking the time to read this review

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Fallout 2 is by far the worst Fallout game I've ever played, a total abomination. Character Customisation: You actually have to put thought into your character, their special points ACTUALLY matter through the game, if that isn't enough to bore you to tears, I don't know what will. Way too much thinking and planning.Speech: How the hell do I get quests? Everyone in every town always wants to make conversation with me about pointless nonsense, like as if you were having an actual conversation with a person? Seriously? A horrendous design flaw. And don't even get me started on the options for speech, way too many. I need to take a break just reading one paragraph of text.Factions: So It turns out that there MORE THAN TWO FACTIONS in this game. And you actually have to talk to them, and worst of all, they all have their own motives and goals for you to learn about? why should I care about the history of vault city? Or why the enclave are there? Fallout 3 did it much better, good vs evil is so much simpler. A lot less character in the npcs and more killing. Like a good Fallout game.Story: If you want a snore fest of a story based around topics such as human evolution, science, vengeance, slavery and long list of boring, broad and ethical topics, this is the story for you. But for the real Fallout fans, just go to 3. The story is 1000 times better than this garbage.Boss encounters: Why would anyone want to waste time having a final conversation with the boss, learning about their motives and their goals and even potiential sparing of their lives, when I could just kill them? A waste of everyone's time.Map/Travelling: The worst map in all of Fallout's history, why would I want to travel a realistic world where people have naturally built places far away for tactical and territorial gains when in Fallout 3 Every location is close to each other? You'd think they would have thought of that earlier. If you want to play a good Fallout game, play Fallout 3 or 4. Not this garbage.

number of helpful: 26 of 28 people (93%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Oh boy, where should we start? Well, at the very least, in 2016 this game still manages to make me completely forget about everything else (including other games from this series) and forces me to spend a week or so on another playthrough. This game is not perfect, but it doesn’t matter: it captivates with benefits, while allowing to ignore the disadvantages. Bugs are pesky though, as well as newer OS compability.Pros:Engulfing atmosphere. The whole world is marvelously crafted to be believable and interesting. Poor cities look like a crumbling mess, striving to survive, rich cities shine in the Wastes, contain quests connected to political issues around the post-apocalyptic California and involve a lot more features that you could imagine.Simple and effective RPG-system. Famous S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system didn’t change a lot from the previous game, but everything else did. Level cap - 99, you could say there is none, and this allows for unlimited potential for any character. Perks & Traits revamped and adjusted. Skills are now much harder to develop. As a general reminder, this game allows you to create a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character that speaks in grunts. What’s not to love?Gruesome combat system. It is more unbalanced than Fallout 1’s combat system, but it delivers much more fun than previously. No more 8 HP human critters - people tend to live longer and hit harder. “Gore”-geous gore, get it? Death animations are extremely satisfying. The whole process of trying to squeeze multiple actions into 5 to 16 possible action points is engaging and rewarding when done properly.Possibility to become a pornstar and arm wrestle wtih supermutant (your punishment for loss is getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, sell your friends, drugs, weapons or Elvis pictures for money, get involved in a shotgun wedding, talk♥♥♥♥♥♥to an army officer via network, etc. Lots of dark humor.Cons:Bugs on bugs. Crashes, save corruptions, graphical glitches. Get ready to google patches and fixes.Bizarre amount of pop and cultural references. Even though I listed dark humor as a good thing, sometimes this game just throws a lot of stuff at you, like quotes, characters, etc. This is not a great thing for me, surely it maybe not a good thing for others. Fallout 1 is a better choice for a more “serious” post-apocalyptic adventure.Old graphics. Aside from meaty execution animations, graphics aged poorly. Not a turn-off for old cavalry, but it is a disadvantage that’s present.In general: 11/10 game, cult status, prospering series. If you say “post-apocalypse RPG”, Fallout is the first thing that comes to mind. And this part is the pinnacle of it. Surely, Fallout 3 is better in combining old and new, but Fallout 2 is superior in everything else, and not only inside the series itself.I’ve gotten a lot farther than I should have. But then again I’ve never met any other game like this either. My ride’s over, folks. Time to play.

Posted: January 15
In this game, you can:>Enter the Temple of Trials and disarm the raised plate traps for extra experience to level up before leaving>Kill a bunch of rats for some reason>Get a car>Convince a fellow tribal to follow you>Murder children and get a permanent perk that stays with you for the rest of the game and makes everyone hate you>Join a drug war>Watch innocent farmers get killed by an intellegent Super Mutant Behemoth in Power Armor.>Blow things up>Sneak>Talk to zombies>Get irradiated>Do someone else's job for them>Have a kid that brings the entire drug cartel to it's knees but never meet him>Find the GECK early and break the game>Lockpick>Get married forever>Do it for Johnny>Become a citizen>"Solve" the leaking power plant problem>Kill everything>Sleep sometimes to restore health>Get a Louisville Slugger that has an absolutely insane amount of knockback.>Consult the spirits>Listen to Myron ramble nonsense about how he "made" Jet with Brahmin manure.>Fix a Brahmin's broken leg>Protect moo-moos from the bug-men>Turn people into goo>Burn things with a Flamethrower>End Turn>Find Vault 13>Forget to Save before quitting>Arm wrestle a Super Mutant>Ask your grumpy aunt for some flint>You missed>You missed>You missed>You missed>You missed>You missed>You missed>You missedHere's a tip for you: Always spend enough skill points in Unarmed or Melee Weapons to get at least 30 in either one. This will improve your accuracy. You will miss quite often in the Temple of Trials, but don't get discouraged; you've still got plenty of room to grow, and if you distribute your skill points correctly, the rest of the game should make it much easier to hit things.And that's not ever scratching the surface of what you can do. Games like this aren't for everyone, but if you don't have a problem with reading a lot (it is an RPG), then you should at least try this game. It's one of my favorite games ever, as I have owned the original disc far longer than I've had an account on Steam. I strongly recommend you try to play it, even if you don't like it in the end.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
Fallout 2 is my favorite RPG. If you have played it, I hope you enjoy it too!If not, give it a chance sometime. It took me about 80 hours to complete.PROS:+ Turn-based tactical RPG action that doesn't mess around+ Almost every character skill has a very good reason to invest in, unlike Fallout 1, a major improvement from the original+ Hilariously violent, painstakingly crass world to explore and subjugate; leave your safe spaces and idealisms at the door, as you will do terrible things throughout the game (and enjoy it)+ Lots to see and do, oodles of secret content+ Many quests have multiple outcomes that persist throughout to the end, often with obscure ways to complete+ Says the "f*ck" and "sh*t" words, way before you saw it in the console world, relays tone of the world+ You can be a porn star+ Kids steal your stuff and sell back to you at a markup+ Michael Dorn (Worf from the Star Trek) is in it+ No autosave or V.A.T.S. crap; git gud baby+ Untainted by the Bethesda Fallout canonCONS:- Runs like absolute garbage on newer machines; crashes at the worst times(your milage may vary depending on how much you want to invest in playing this game)- The 'meatier' gameplay elements like Action Points and Sequence can be a little daunting for some, mostly unfamiliar players

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Fallout 2 is a game that went under my games to play radar for far too long, mostly because when it came out I wasn't even   in primary school yet. I'm typically not the biggest fan of this kind of post-apocalyptic setting, in fact this is the only one I like. I owe my discovering this masterpiece entirely to the streamlined fallout experience by Bethesda and later Obsidian.I found the first dungeon to be ruthless my first playthrough, it took me a reload or two before I managed to survive the initial trial and start the main quest. When I emerged into the wasteland of Fallout 2, I was a bit intimidated, every direction on the map had opened up to me. The main quest giver did point me in the direction of a nearby town, but I wanted to see how far south I could go, maybe discover a cool town or two. Nope, I just ended up with plenty of bullets in my corpse. I decide to not go south when I reload and instead go to the town that the elder directed me to, this is where I lost interest initially. I ended up not in the mood to read any of the dialogs that would've pointed me in the right direction and instead gave up. A few months pass and on a whim I decide to reload my save and see if I can't make any headway in game. After I did a few side quests I really started to enjoy myself, the battle system I found unforgiving started to feel a little rewarding, and I kept going.I am a little sad however, I'm nearing the final content of the game and I'm trying my darndest to make my remaining hours on my character, the powerfist wielding warrior Gertrude, last as long as possible.PROS:-The game has aged well in my opinion, the graphics may not look as sharp as some people may desire, but the game is  still entirely playable.-The combat is very fun after the initial slow burn, I'd say about level 5 is where it took off for me.-The characters have been very fun, I can recall most of the characters I've run into in Fallout 2, the same can't be said of Fallout 3 or New Vegas (granted they each had a few good characters).-Tons of content, I've spent a good 30-40 hours on my current character and still find new quests.CONS:-The game is from the late 90's and has technical limitations because of this (Combat can be very slow when a large number of characters are engaged in battle)-You cannot reload in combat when it is not your turn to move, this doesn't sound too bad but in large battles where you try to keep your companions alive it can be a little bothersome.-There is a time limit in game for how long you can play, it's an unfortunate technical issue, however you have about 13 in game years until you are forced to play a new character (my current character is on year 3 near the end of the game)Final thoughts on the game:This is honestly the best game I've played in past years, it makes me yearn for games that don't constantly hold my hand. Every mistake I make is punished, every good decision I make is rewarded. The myriad of companions in game really made my experience that much better (barring when Sulik would sit in doorways, blocking my only exit). If I had to give this game a number score it'd probably be an 8 or 9 out of 10. There is no perfect game, and this game certainly has quite  a large number of faults, but this is the most fun I've had with a game since my initial Dark Souls playthrough.

content:
Posted: April 14
My review of Fallout also goes for Fallout 2, which took everything that made Fallout great and made it bigger, better, more complex, allowing even more solutions to quests and puzzles. Here the history of the Fallout universe was fleshed out in ways that remain essential to this day. Whereas Fallout was shrouded in mystery and uncertainty, Fallout 2 explored the darkest corners of the post-nuclear world, unafraid to face what lurked in them. In fact it often laughs in the face of the most morbid and dark situations. It was a game for mature audiences in a decade when most games were still trying to be accessible to everyone.The companions are one of the best improvements: whereas Fallout only had four companions and the interactions with them were very limited (mostly talking pack-mules), Fallout 2 offers a total of fourteen recruitable companions with great mechanics of interaction and combat control, which would resurface in Fallout: New Vegas with further refinement. In fact, the way companions work in Fallout 2 is the basis for the brilliant character development that New Vegas would offer many years later. Two of the companions even have their own talking heads, with some very decent facial animation for the technology of the time.The possibility of rebuilding a nuclear-powered car is also a great improvement. Travelling in the wasteland can often be a nuisance, especially when you just want to get to your destination. With the Highwayman you can usually skip over encounters and get from A to B much faster. The trunk is also very useful to stash your loot. The best part is that it's not easy to get the car, not like when you get the first power armor in Fallout 4: it's not just handed to you, you have to work for it, do some quests, find ways to improve it and so on, which makes it much more rewarding when you finally hit the road.While it may seem a bit silly at first, the saga of the Chosen One makes tribalism in the post-nuclear world very compelling and unique. On the surface, what starts as a very long fetch quest becomes in fact a saga that makes perfect sense in the grand scheme of the game, especially when you get to the Enclave Oil Rig. It's an indictment of the very foundation of the United States government, and this was five years before the invasion of Iraq.It is also full of whacky moments and plot twists that later would be poorly imitated. From talking Deathclaws to Chinese computers; from porn studios to midgets who call you a Mad Max wannabe; several instances of characters breaking the fourth wall, and so on. The combination of very dark and adult themes mixed with some very silly jokes is something very unique to this game: it includes an actual Easter egg as an item that does nothing at all.This is not a game for everyone. The first few hours are even more difficult, but if you played Fallout you'll already be used to the UI and have some good sense of how to build a character that can survive and fight. Once you have some good gear and one or two companions to have your back, it's impossible to put it down. It's a long ride: you'll meet many fascinating, lifelike characters; you'll visit great cities and run-down villages; you'll explore caves and vaults; you'll mess around with different ways to accomplish a quest and choose an approach that suits your character; you'll make decisions and live with the consequences. This is what Fallout is and was always about.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
"War, war never changes!"War remained the same when Fallout 2 was released a year after its predecessor. It was back in 1998 and it was a jolly good time to be a gamer. This game was the perfect example of "not fixing what isn't broken". So, game mechanics were pretty much the same while the game world became much, much larger.Storywise we control a Vault Dweller once more - in fact, our protagonist is the descendant of the hero of the first game - who's tasked to save his establishment by acquiring the so-called G.E.C.K., a device with such a power that it can restore completely damaged environments to their default state.Naturally, the "bigger the better" concept was followed by introducing a wider range of weapons and enemies and, of course, new environments. We also have more skills, perks and beside Karma we also have a Reputation. Something that is constantly changing along the way as we make progress by completing subquests. You can be attacked in a new town if you have a bad reputation -  settlements are not independent of one another; if you complete a deed somewhere it may very well be heard of elsewhere.Finally, recruitable characters seem to be much, much better. We have total control over them by being able to issue orders, help them level up and provide equipment. Just make sure you have the necessary Karma to be able to recruit them - not that you don't have enough to get to know. With all the new stuff introduced Fallout 2 requires much more time to complete - if you're a completionist you can expect to spend 50-60 hours with the sequel. And, of course, like in case of all such RPGs you can start a new game, pick a different level-up method, solve quests in a different way and hire different people to be at your service.I spent dozens of hours with this game when it came out. I remember being happy of having our own car (called Highwayman) which then could easily disappear (in fact, the game had a related bug which needed to be patched at the time). If you did not pay attention you could lost it forever. It was a shame as it made travelling between towns fast and easy.Fallout 2 is a classic. And it comes patched on Steam which allows us to pick a higher resolution. If you have invested hundreds of hours into Fallout 3 et al you might as well check where it all started back in the '90s.

number of helpful: 29 of 38 people (76%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												      Fallout 3 was one of my favorite all-time games. Naturally, I thought at one point, "I've played Fallout 3 and New Vegas, but I've never even heard of Fallout 1 or 2. I wonder what they are like?"      Well my question has since been answered. And my god, Fallout 2 is one of the greatest games made. As most people do, let's go through pros and cons. I'd also like to say that I haven't played this game in a long time, so I'm going off memory.PROS:~Story elements. You are The Chosen One, or if you are me, Penguin Johnson. You are the descendant of the Vault Dweller, a member of Vault HMHMHM (woops I can't remember) who saved his/her vault from certain doom by dehydration, when he went out into the wastes to get a Water Purification Chip. Your tribe is dying, brahmin and crops are dying as well. And only one thing can save it. I bet you guessed, "Me!" HAH! DON'T MAKE ME LAUGH! No, a G.E.C.K. In fact, if you were the saviour of the tribe, then they would be doomed because of this games...~Difficulty. Fallout 3, while I died a few times, wasn't that difficult. However, when you ask this game for help, it flips you off, and says how about you deal with that guy with a machine gun yourself? It then proceeds to laugh as the machine gun guy burst fires and kills you instantly with a critical hit that does 78 damage, and you only had 5 health. You WILL see the death screen a lot if you are new to this game, but that's an element that makes it good.~So much to explore. This game, has you traversing THE ENTIRETY OF THE UNITED STATES! From San Fransisco, to Klamath. What's that? Never heard of Klamath? Where have you been living, anywhere but in Fallout 2?~So many weapons! You got your pistols, sub machine guns, assault rifles, snipers, shotguns, knives, blunt weapons, fists, fist weapons, light machine guns, miniguns, plasma weapons, laser weapons, and probably even more. And there are a lot of weapons in each of those categories.~Characters. Characters are so unique. You have the ghoul from... the ghoul place who makes a joke about what assuming does. (It makes an♥♥♥♥♥out of you and me). Then you got the leader of Vault City, who I shot many times out of pure  annoyance.NEGATIVES:-This game, is so broken. I'm not kidding. You know how people say Fallout New Vegas is glitchy? NV is the tip of the iceburg of glitches, and this is the entire thing. Luckily, people have made a total conversion mod which fixes most of the game. It's called Project Purification or something like that. I can't remember.-SPOILER ALERT! When you get the G.E.C.K. Why? Because SPOILER ALERT AGAIN the Enclave just kills your entire tribe anyway. What was the point? At least I can get revenge on them. Seriously. You have to. It's a main quest to wipe the Enclave out.So what do I give this game? 7/10. If you didn't have to download a mod this would have been a 9/10 easily, but unfortunately, that's just such a big problem that I can't. But, get that mod, and you will be embarking on a journey, through war. And as they say, war. War never changes. THAT WAS A REFERENCE THANKS FOR COMING!

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												(In addition, I have hundreds of hours on the original retail version)Where to begin?  This is one of my all-time favorite games, and I grew up with it along with the first game. It was part of my childhood and continues to be a part of my life all these years later, and it will always have a place in my heart.  Fallout 2 is excellent and anyone who likes RPGs who aren't afraid to play a game that isn't entirely welcoming should give it a shot; I admit I am somewhat biased because of my nostalgia but that doesn't explain the entirety of why I think this is an excellent game.  There is *much* more to this game than the references, humor and fourth wall breaking; that being said, the humor is a nice touch depending on your tastes.  This game deserves as much attention and recognition as the first in the series and I consider both games to be one in the same and part of the same collective experience.This is game is punishing in certain ways, and is not that casual of an experience; and in some ways I would admit that this game isn't the most welcoming, but once you figure things out and start to progress there are numerous different possibilities and choices laid out before you, and you can play any type of character you choose and have any type of temperament you choose in this game world, which is rich and unique.Fallout 1 and 2 haven't aged very well, although personally I can transcend that completely due to my nostalgia and attachment to the series; the game looks better now since we can change the screen resolution, and the game is even better with the Restoration Project mod.You are the grandchild of the Vault Dweller from Fallout 1, the game takes place 80 years after the first game, and you are part of a primitive tribe which your ancestor founded.  You must save your tribe by finding the holy GECK.  Along the way in your quest, you can do many interesting things and talk to many interesting characters.The gameplay is the same as in Fallout 1, aside from a few things like starting skills being calculated differently and starting at different levels. Fallout 2 is much longer and there is much more to do and see in Fallout 2 than the first (especially with the Restoration Project mod), although the first game is excellent for many of the same reasons this game is excellent.  Most people who enjoyed Fallout 1 (or similar titles) will probably enjoy this immensely also.  I would even recommend this game to people who don't normally play games like it, but are merely very interested in the Fallout lore.There is an issue I have with the game but only due to playing it on newer, larger displays and playing it on a higher resolution than the game was initially intended for; certain scenes will look wrong if the resolution is set high.In conclusion, this isn't for everyone and not everyone will be able to enjoy it in the same capacity as others might, for whatever reasons, whether it has to do with the age of the game or not.  But this is classic Fallout and deserves as much love as the first in the series.  This game is highly recommended for any fan of oldschool turn-based RPGs, this and its predecessor helped to redefine the genre. This game is old, but it's excellent and one of the best RPGs I've played, and is very well written.I'd also highly recommend the Restoration Project mod, which includes the Unofficial Patch.  It restores new content into the game that the developers intended to have in the first place but weren't able to, and  you can choose which options you would like to install easily. killap.net

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												Nearly twenty years after the fact, this is still my favorite RPG. With the exception of New Vegas, this was the last official Fallout game in which the skill system was, in fact, meaningful and had a significant effect on gameplay.Do you want to be something of a pacifist, with high speech, intelligence, and survivalist skills who runs for cover at the first sign of a fight and has his companions do all the heavy lifting for him? Go for it, Skeeter.How about a post-apocalyptic hard♥♥♥♥♥who just wants to make a living skinning giant geckos and selling off discarded raider gear? You can do that too. The game does have a story and it is actually pretty good, but you're likely going to spend more time doing just about everything else than you are folliwng the main plot, and that is a very good thing.The graphics have not aged particularly well, and the game takes some minor adjusting on a modern rig in order to make it work and look properly, but seriously, don't let that stop you. Once you get used to the visual style, the pixel hunt-like searches for items dropped on the floor becomes the least of your concerrns.You will be far more interested in the cavalcade of goodies that's just fallen to the ground alongside the raider whose chest you've blasted a whole clear through.Also you can murder children, and acquire a perk which reflects said habit of killing children. Game of the year, all years.

content:
Posted: February 22
												It's hard not to recommend a game like this.  Being the sequel to one of the best computer RPGs ever created, it had very big shoes to fill, yet it managed to fill them.  It's a big adventure, with plenty of places to see and quests to complete.  And best of all, you can go about it pretty much any way you want.  Be it by trickery, stealth, or just plain violence, there are usually multiple solutions to any problem in the game.  Indeed, if you feel like it, you can kill  anyone (yes, even the children) who literally or figuratively stands in your way.  It won't be easy, and there will usually be consequences, but it can be done. However, the game is not very beginner friendly.  Those coming from Fallaout 3, New Vegas, and 4 will likely be frustrated to find themselves missing half or more of their attacks at early levels.  Not to mention the frequent encounters of 5+ enemies at a time while you're travelling, each of which takes a turn each round.  This can result in lengthy encounters which end badly for you.  If you stick with it, however, and pace yourself while also building your character to survive, these encounters will soon become a piece of cake, or a thing of the past altogether.  In all, a fantastic experience awaits you with Fallout 2, and if you have the time and patience for it, you'll in for a hell of a ride.  One final note: if you played New Vegas and found the "Wild Wasteland" jokes to be more annoying than funny, then take heed: this game's humor is like Wild Wasteland on jet.  Seriously.  You can't go ten minutes in this game without some character breaking the fourth wall, or making some pop-culture reference or other.  Some of them are really good, but if you're like me, you'll find yourself tired of them quickly

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												22 of my 50 hours of gameplay are of the actual Fallout 2 - I have that one memorized backwards since I was ~14, the rest I spent on the superb fanmade seq/prequel, Fallout 1.5: Resurrection. This is going to be 2 reviews in one and I can't say that I care if that's okay or not.Fallout 1.5: Resurrectionstays true to the old school Fallout vibe and is aptly named with the mod being very much in-between Fallout 1 and 2. Resurrection starts in 2170, 8-9 years after Fallout 1 and well before 2241, the starting year of Fallout 2. You'll have to deal with the aftermath of the dispersion of the Master's super mutant army. Story wise Resurrection is closer to Fallout 1, being a lot more serious, mature and scientifically plausible than Fallout 2. In comparison, it seems Creative had their drawers stacked to the brim with jokes and pop culture references that then required a game to be built around them with Fallout 2.I did figure out the main plot at about the 10 minute point, but generally I very much enjoyed discovering another piece of the Fallout universe.I've even made a modest walkthrough in case you're a perfectionist and want to get it 'right' the first time around:


Fallout 1.5: Resurrection To Do List 
A Guide for Fallout 2
By: Lauri

			During my first play-through I found myself missing at least some general outline of what can be done in each city. Maybe you're like me.		


Fallout 2The overwhelmingly positive reviews others have left should convince anyone who hasn't played classic Fallout yet to change their ways, so I'm not even going to go into every aspect of the game.As I've already mentioned, Fallout 2 is a lot more jokey than its predecessor, featuring a ghost, aliens, a super mutant magician, talking mole rats, Skynet, Mike Tyson, civil deathclaws, Tragic: The Garnering, scientologists named Juan Cruz and Vicki Goldman and the POTUS to name a few. If it's hard to imagine a story arc that incorporates all of these seamlessly then you're probably on to something. I can't say that all this humor is somehow bad though, just know that Fallout 1 and 2 are different and you may find the latter not quite what you would've expected.I've read a few reviews that call Fallout 2 'slow' and being a total fanboy had to stop and think for a second to digest this criticism, but it's true. 2's story starts off really boring and I applaud any millennial that can sit through Arroyo and Klamath without deleting the game. Without using Cheat Engine or somesuch, shooting and missing a rat or gecko for the 23rd time really is for the dead-of-brain. But I swear from The Den and on the game improves by an order of magnitude with the high points coming in New Reno, which provides much to do in itself (like boxing and starring in porn) beside being a nexus for many quests from other towns.A small annoyance I noticed during my female playthrough was that Fallout 2 is very obviously a game by guys, for guys. Male PCs get a whole extra ending for New Reno, can donate sperm to alleviate the inbreeding situation in Vault City and have dozens of extra pervy dialogue options to use compared to females who can at most suck D to save a few hundred caps here and there. Caps, by the way, which are infinite after you get to ~120% in gambling. Can't say I blame Black Isle too much though because if you think of how many people owned a computer in 1998, played games on it, had the intellectual capacity to grok RPGs and out of that tiny sliver of the population, how many were women, well... peddling encyclopedias at Bible study might have been a better business model than catering to girls with Fallout 2.As customary with RPGs, save often and into different slots. I recommend always keeping around a save from the first second you arrive in a new marked location so you could replay it if need be.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Originally released by in 1998, I never really had the chance to play Fallout 2, mostly due to the fact I was too busy being born. Having got wrapped up into the Fallout 3 hype train, I became rather enthralled in the franchise itself. So, several years later, I picked it up and…...in an attempt to not color my already vibrant opinion of the nearly twenty year old title to nothing but what can be considered felatio, let me just be a bit hypercritical about the game. The most glaring “problem” is what Fallout: New Vegas suffers from, by basically being the same game twice, effectively Fallout 2.0. While it didn’t work to the determent of the more modern entries, it hurts the overall visual experience with the sprites being rather noticeably polarized. Most are ripped straight from the original, built by pixels and with limited frame to frame animation. Then you have the newer 3D rendered sprites with smoother animation, creating an immersion breaking experience. Thankfully, these sprites don’t really appear in the same cell often, but when they do it is noticeably. Another problem they never fixed was the ♥♥♥♥ING INVENTORY UI! Its clumsy and finicky at best, with the mouse cursor deciding the change sensitivity like a pregnant women. You will work around it eventually, but it just infuriates me how this aspect was never fixed. Its horrid but manages to get the job done.Getting down on my knees, everything else is, the world, leveling system, character's, weapon variety and quest are, to put it broadly, ♥♥♥♥ING FANTASTIC. While the characters are a tad uninspired and two dimensional, and the story banal, Fallout 2 is possibly one of the best Western RPGs ever made. The leveling system grants satisfaction, managing to maintain this by having “Perks”(effectively permanent stat or combat boosts) that you receive every other level. You can’t help but wanting to progress with the prospect of nearly sawing men in half with not much but as dainty slap.The world can be summarized as a sour salted candy advertised as extremely so, its daunting at first and WILL kick you♥♥♥♥♥once you pop it in you gob, but will eventually become remarkable sweet. Southern California is huge, being exceptionally difficult during the early game but incredibly rewarding later down the line. The only problem I have with the world is the lack of variety, but I feel the questing can make up for this. I feel developers can live or die by the hand holding die. Choosing to do so makes the game a breeze, and choosing not to has the potential to make progress come to a screeching halt. Fallout 2 gives you just enough information to get on with the question without some patronizing arrow pointing out where to go. And can even have you thinking about solutions for the rare puzzle here and there. Quest are satisfying and varied to an insane degree.Fallout 2 might possibly be one of the few games in which you likely won’t see every weapon or outcome. If you ♥♥♥♥ up, you ♥♥♥♥ed up and there is no turning back, with some things being consequently cut off. Prompting actual thought and replay-ability, I love this idea. The weapons on the other hand, are insanely variant. Its not the fact that a quest outcome closes them off from you, it's the fact there are so ♥♥♥♥ing many that you're unlikely to even find them all. Whether this works for the games prosperity or detriment.Regardless, with its negatives and positives in check, Fallout 2 is one of the greatest title I have ever played. Even with its missteps, no matter how small, they pale to what the game does right. Of fantastic value, Fallout 2 is a must buy title, no matter its age.Verdict: 9.5 - Fantastic

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I would like to begin my review by saying I started the Fallout series with 3 (I know shameful right?) But soon learned about the first two games and how different they were from Bethesda's Fallout 3. At first, I thought they looked horrible with their dated graphics and gameplay. But after reading hours upon hours of lore and story tidbits on the Fallout Gamepedia, I just knew I had to play them. I was on Xbox 360 at the time so I couldn't play them yet, so I figured I would play New Vegas in the meantime.Anyways, eventually I got my PC, and one of the first games I got on their was the entire Classic Fallout Collection. I played through 1 first, I loved it. Then, after a long break, I started Fallout 2. I was blown away by it's atmosphere and compelling story. Even though I am not used to turn-based gameplay, I have come to enjoy it because of Fallout and Fallout 2. The game makes you think about your moral desicions and the consequences they bring, something Bethesda games could never really do. For example, if you kill a child bounty hunters will chase you down and everybody will hate you, discouraging you from doing such evil things. I highly recommend this game to any Fallout fan, even the new ones like me. This is definitely my favorite RPG game, and maybe even my favorite game. 10/10

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												I have to admit, at first, I had difficulty adapting to the isometric style of this game, my first fallout being new Vegas after all, but after playing for a few hours, I was hooked. This game is possibly my 2nd favourite in the entire franchise (the first being New Vegas). The game has content for hours, 200+ hours into the game and I'm still finding new things as I go along. The combat is easy to learn, but can be punishing if you don't adapt to the isometric style quickly. There is a large variation of weapons and armour for your character to use. There are also companions (with varying levels of usefulness) who can back you up in combat or help you with various tasks you may come across in the wasteland. There are a wide variety of interesting and vibrant characters to meet, from gangsters to ghouls, Soldiers to slavers. There are plenty of quests and locations to complete and explore. I cannot stress enough how good this game is, it has more content that fallout 4 and it has all the charm of New Vegas. I would give it an 9/10. it's a masterpiece that has more content than most modern games have.

content:
Posted: January 5
												I was afraid that Fallout 2 might've been too outdated for me at first, that it wouldn't be entertaining or worth the time.Oh boy I was wrong. I'd say it's the best Fallout game I've played so far (haven't played the first one yet but I'll get to that someday).The combat feels satisfying and its turn-based gameplay seems to have aged well, though, it might be a bit slow at times and can be very punishing because of them lethal critical hits. But there's a lot of options to fiddle around with to personalize the type of experience you want, same goes with the game's great characterization system where you can create a lot of different builds.Game's tough at the start but if you give it time and try to make some progress you'll surely get well rewarded, because of the loot you get after hard-fought battles feels worthy enough for you to want progress even further. The dialogues are really well written too, there are a lot of different options you can choose from depending on what stats you invested in, which can lead to some really amusing conversations. For instance, high intelligence with the speech skill mostly provides with the most available options, but even low intelligence comes with unique dialogue or reactions from NPCs throughout the world.Choices you make does actually feel like it has consequences, it also affect the game's ending to a large scale. So the replayability is there if you want to tackle the game with an entirely different approach.The whole plot in this game is also a pretty thrilling experience the more progress you make, it's very gritty and has this dark atmosphere to it which I love. I also do think the game's soundtrack and visuals have a big impact on the game's atmosphere and that it's really well done. I'm happy I decided to pick this game up, even bought it during a sale for a few dollars.So money well spent I'd say. If you're a fan of the RPG genre you should definitely get this game, Fallout 2 is the classic RPG you wouldn't want to miss.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												One of the best RPGs ever created. Period. And probably best of post-apocalyptic games of all time.Pros.- Absolute freedom within a strictly linear plot (paradox?): you can finish your mission.. if you want. Or go somewhere to find something. Or kill anyone in sight. It's up to you. Playing this game is so much more fun than finishing it..- Totally unpredictable random encounters (on first playthrough, but anyway): getting in the midlle of gangfight? check. saving innocent farmers from wildlife? check. saving innocent wildlife from some bad trappers? check, and don't mind if wildlife would try to eat you, it's just their way to say "thanks". getting one-hitted by gigant predatory lizard? check. finding an extremely OP weapon being level 2-3 right after you leave starting location? check, if you'll find a way to actually get your hands on that weapon without dying.- Special encounters: no spoilers, you must find them all by yourself.- You and only you choose how you would play: kill bad people and get praised by others (actually not), kill good people (and get your butt hunted for that), don't kill anyone ever (it's even possible to win the game that way, with only one exception), aimlessly wander around exploring, become a gangster (almost), help some people with their problems (or help other people with those problematic jerks). Your choice is only thing that matters.- Side quests: they make up about 95% of all quests you'll get. Yes, you could finish the game and see about 5% of content only. But take one step aside from main quest - and a brave new world will open before you.- Easter eggs: there are plenty. Nuff said. Go find them.- Combat: totally unpredictable even on your 144 playthrough. Critical oneshot with a 7% chance to hit? Easy. Missing target with 95% hit chance while it's staying in front of you? Easy. Killing three random targets with minigun - out of five standing before you EXCEPT YOUR ACTUAL TARGET? Very easy. Killing yourself with a critical miss? Not that easy, but possible.- You can actually kill these annoying little critters: yes, it's about kids. Name another game where you are allowed to do such horrible thing at last? No more immortal godly beings that wander around, annoy you and steal from your pockets. Be warned: people of wasteland won't like you for that (and your♥♥♥♥♥would be hunted).Cons.- Too much myths about cut content: there are some really beatifull things that didn't get to the final version. Maybe they  existed, maybe not.- Map: after 4-5 playthroughs you will get everywhere and find everything. Maybe sooner, maybe later, but that will happen. There are so much empty space on the map, so many lost opportunities to place something exciting.. not to mention that map from first game could've been added to second.- Replayability dissapears after 50-60 times. Seriously, what else could you do when you've done everything possible?Total score: 9.7/10. Almost perfect.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2012
												Fallout 2 is the sequel to one of my favorite RPG's of all time and it does a superb job of the lifting the mantle of the original Fallout even if it does have it's flaws.Fallout 2 sets you as the descendant of the original Vault Dweller who we now learned founded a small tribe near the Californian coast following the events of the original. This tribe has now fallen on hard times and as the direct descendant of the Vault Dweller you are charged with going out into the world and finding a mythical Vault device known as the G.E.C.K. This device, the elder of your village believe, have the power to turn the part of the wasteland into an utopia and ensure the tribe's future.You start off the game with a somewhat lackluster tutorial that introduces you to the basic elements of the game however it is only once you leave this initial area and are ready to depart your childhood village for the first time that the game truly comes into it's own. The massive world map at your feet with no restrictions on where to go and who to see.The mechanics are much the same as the original. Isometric turn-based role playing game using the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system for character development. It is however in the open nature of the game that you find it's soul. Made a female character with high charisma? You might be able to charm, or sleep, your way past several encounters. Made a character with incredibly low intelligence? All of the sudden your dialog responses are just various grunts and the people you encounter will treat you as a freak of nature.Even most of the storyline can be skipped if you know where to go and almost every task you are given in the game can be solved in a myriad of ways, many options not even becoming apparent to you unless you have the needed skills or made some particular choices beforehand.The game does have some shortcomings. The 4th wall breaking that was rare in the original are much more commonplace and several characters and areas just feel out of place with the rest of the game.New Reno in particular, a gambling town complete with mafia families fighting for control and a working porn studio takes you completely out of the game and makes for a rather disappointing experience.Fallout 2 has all the qualities that made the original one of the greatest RPG's ever and it improves on many aspects of it with better companion AI and a much larger map. It's faults however do weight heavily and keep it from surpassing it's predecessor. It is still one of the greatest RPG's ever to be made and if you are a fan of open ended RPG games and intelligent story and dialog then it should be a definite purchase.
