Posted: January 5, 2016
												Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a role-playing open world game featuring a considerably larger map/world and a far more extensive storyline, than those of Fallout 1. It is hands down one of the best games I've ever played (and that says a lot about it). The fact that the game was made in 1998 makes it even more impressive.Fallout 2 centres around the protagonist a.k.a. 'The Chosen One' and is entasked with the duty by the elder of his village to find and retrieve the Garden Eden Creation Kit (G.E.C.K.) which is a device that can create thriving communities out of the post-apocalyptic wasteland.The game comprises of exploring and travelling in the open world as well as speech and quests to various characters and NPC. In addition to the role playing elements, a unique turn-based shooter is used during combat. This incredible blend  makes the game so widely stimulating and intense. It is an experience unlike one other. Not to mention the storyline is as engaging as it is compelling.The player's actions throughout the game dictate what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. A player can choose to inhibit/aid certain NPCs and affects the entire gameplay. Aside from combat, speech also plays a huge role in the final outcome of the game. Before the game begins, the player is allowed to create his/her character with a variety of different skill, perk, trait and character point (S.P.E.C.I.A.L) builds. Because of the extensive outcome and scenarios, Fallout 2 is a game with incredibly high replay value.There is not much else to say, this game is IN-F***ING-CREDIBLE!GET IT (if you haven't already)6*/5 - 110% would recommend

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a role-playing open world game featuring a considerably larger map/world and a far more extensive storyline, than those of Fallout 1. It is hands down one of the best games I've ever played (and that says a lot about it). The fact that the game was made in 1998 makes it even more impressive.Fallout 2 centres around the protagonist a.k.a. 'The Chosen One' and is entasked with the duty by the elder of his village to find and retrieve the Garden Eden Creation Kit (G.E.C.K.) which is a device that can create thriving communities out of the post-apocalyptic wasteland.The game comprises of exploring and travelling in the open world as well as speech and quests to various characters and NPC. In addition to the role playing elements, a unique turn-based shooter is used during combat. This incredible blend  makes the game so widely stimulating and intense. It is an experience unlike one other. Not to mention the storyline is as engaging as it is compelling.The player's actions throughout the game dictate what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. A player can choose to inhibit/aid certain NPCs and affects the entire gameplay. Aside from combat, speech also plays a huge role in the final outcome of the game. Before the game begins, the player is allowed to create his/her character with a variety of different skill, perk, trait and character point (S.P.E.C.I.A.L) builds. Because of the extensive outcome and scenarios, Fallout 2 is a game with incredibly high replay value.There is not much else to say, this game is IN-F***ING-CREDIBLE!GET IT (if you haven't already)6*/5 - 110% would recommend

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Fallout 4 is a great game, but it is not a great Fallout game.Fallout 2, this game right here, was the first truly post-apocalyptic RPG where every choice had consequences, your character stats mattered, and the replayability of another character was NOT just cookie-cutter. You could actually build a character too weak to survive the first zone, instead of just doing 10% more damage with weapom type x.You most certainly did not get laser weapons, power armor, and a minigun to kill a deathclaw from an elevated position in your first play session. Your choices did not all result in the same outcome, nobody held your hand through a tutorial (in fact, you probably died in the first 5 minutes), and you the player could not over-ride your character's abilities by aiming better or jumping on top of something or or or ...I only have 41.3 hrs on record with the Steam re-release. However, I have two worn-out CD-ROM discs, a playable third in a binder, a GoG version somewhere, and a very real understanding of video game addiction.

Posted: February 15, 2016
												Fallout 2 is a great game, and perhaps one of the best in the Fallout series. The setting, characters, and music are all wonderful. However, the combat is very dated and the game is infested with bugs. Certain quests and outcomes are simply unobtainable. In addition, I was annoyed that for a game that features many different solutions to complete a task, the game would often force you into doing things during crucial moments that if you had not previously focused upon, would be very difficult to do. Still, I can overlook this and say it is a game that any western rpg player should try out.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												In some ways, this is a direct improvement over the first. There is more stuff to do, more stuff to unlock, bigger map, etc. The character customization is deeper. That's all fine.However, what I appreciated about the first game were its simple objectives with various free-form solutions. Fallout 2 seems to strip these away in favor of increasingly complex and awkward quests. Often, they will require speaking with specific characters who are almost indistinguishable from other, less important NPCs, and doing so in a specific procedure. The Gecko Power Plant quest is a good example of how this, combined with a lot of tedious running around, results in a tiresome game of "who's who". Of course, the player usually has a choice in these sorts of situations to take a moral shortcut for negative karma, but the rewards for pursuing a "good" outcome pretty much always outweigh the rewards for "bad" behavior. I prefer to finish quests in as complete a fashion as I can, but their weird, constricted structure here bores and angers me.Other times, logic is sacrificed for the sake of creating gameplay. I understand that Vault 13, literally a hole in the side of a mountain, could be easily ignored, but if this Pipboy is the same one that belonged to the Vault Dweller, wouldn't it make sense for the locations canonically visited in the previous game to be on it already? At least the military base should be on there, if not the vault, but at least it's not hidden to the point of requiring a quest for exploration; Speaking of bases, what about the Sierra Army Depot? It sounds and looks like it would be big enough to be noticed just by going near it, but nope, it only appears when a certain quest is activated. There's also the Enclave power armor that's good at fooling Enclave soldiers in every situation save for the map's random events, but whatever, I'm sure someone with nothing better to do has come up with an explanation for all this. Bottom line is, the first game did not do this sort of thing. It let the player reap the full benefits of accidental discovery.A large map is good, but the random events happen WAY too often. I breathe less often than I encounter something on the map screen. Almost every time, the enemies appearing in these events are too hard (instant death), too plentiful (slow, agonizing death), or easily outrun (waste of time). Save scumming becomes a necessity for travelling through particularly brutal areas, such as the region around Navarro, where movement needs to be taken an inch at a time, lest I come across a patrol and get a one-way ticket to the game over screen. Get the car, because that♥♥♥♥♥♥happens a lot less often, although there is still the occasional stop made involuntary for whatever reason.Overall, the game is representative of living in modern day California; It's buggy (frame drops, some crashing), very disorganized, and constantly frustrating, but it has its moments, and it gets more fun after the first few hours. Bigger? Yes. Better? Maybe. It's still worth playing.

Posted: November 23, 2016
Nostalgia GaloreWord cannot describe how much I love this game and I have lost count of how many times I have played it from beginning to end. Even though the game is ridiculously bugged and in many ways flawed (in its original form); the gritty grainy charm, the uncompromising dialogue and gory pixilated body explosions on a critical hit or by using a massive enough gun are just unparalleled, even when compared to the more modern instalments of the franchise. The retro pop-50s, hilariously grotesque depiction of a post-apocalyptic future is iconic and unmatched, it creates a post-eschatological environment that is equally gruesome as it is enjoyable. With that said, I love all of the other iterations of the game universe including those done by Bethesda, even Fallout 4, but none of them really compare to Fallout 2, only New Vegas comes close. I cherish my adventures with Sulik and his dialogue with his nose-bone, I laugh every time I buff John Cassidy in the heat of battle but forget his heart condition leading to his demise and of course the possibility of being reunited with Dogmeat from Fallout 1. I also love that you can make a character with such a low intelligence score that virtually all dialogue is impossible (as you are more or less unable to speak) and yet, you can complete the game in a meaningful way. I will be playing this game again and again, and force my children to do that same.And if they refuse, I will disown them. This game is indeed; a kiss to build a dream on..   ** This is a review of the original game, not Bethesda’s polished version.

Posted: January 17
												DISCLAIMER: I play this game with the restored content mod, so everything I say should be taken lightly if your not going to use the mod.Fallout 2 is one of the best games I have probably ever played or will play, the reasons are:1) The combat systems are near perfect, if you like turn based combat.2) The writing is also great, it's very clever and funny.3) The roleplaying is spot on and you can roleplay as pretty much anything.4) It has a ton of content, seriously I've put 100 hours into this game so far, about 70 hours in my first and about 30 so far in my second, and I don't think I did everything in my first playthrough. The only problems I have with this game are purely a result of tthe games age such as puzzles not making sense, and some minor bugs. Overall, Fallout 2 is a great game, and definitly worth $10.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Quite possibly my favorite game in the series, Fallout 2 is an engaging, difficult, and fully immersive showcase into the Fallout world that I've enjoyed perhaps more so than every other Fallout game to date.The game is turnbased, if you hate those games, you will hate this one. That's a fact. But this game offers a depth of play even with that system so much so that I don't mind it in most situations. Towards the end, it will turn into a grind to travel the huge distances necessary, but the color of the game largely makes up for it. There are tons of quests to go through, settlements to interact with, all of which play a part in the ending you find. The ending is like the end of Fallout 3 and New Vegas, where you do the same thing, but the dialogue offers more depending on what you did. The breadth of what can be experienced is great, and its combined Grit, Humor, and Atmosphere really made the game for me.

content:
Posted: March 13
												I'm going to be honest, I despised this game when I first played it. My attacks weren't doing♥♥♥♥♥♥ I was extremely confused on what to do, and hated how it felt. That was months ago, until recently. I sat down, read some tips and tricks and gave this game a shot. Now I've 70 hours in this game. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ blast.Pros:-Interesting and well-developed plot: The more I got in, the more I wanted to see what was going on. The stroy hooked really hooked me in.-Interesting locations: Many locations you visit always have some backstory around them and I gotta say, almost all of them are interesting and awesome to visit like the casino of New Reno with mobsters hanging around running the place or even  Navarro which let's you infiltrate the enclave base as a recruit. -Choices Galore: There are many choices to make in californian wasteland and many I never even knew about until my second playthrough. There's so much you could miss on one playthrough that it makes me want to do another just to see what the other way could have been.-Dialogue and Writing: This game has the best writing in any fallout game hands down. There are many humerous moments that we come to love in fallout, but it knows when to be dark and disturbing. You'll want to talk to everyone just to see what they're gonna say. (Low intelligence runs are the funniest♥♥♥♥♥♥ever)-Combat: This is a hit and miss for some. For me, it's a hit. When you sit down and understand what to do, the combat goes from something you may despise to something you won't mind at all.Cons:-Confusion: This game can be pretty confusing at times. Don't be afraid to pull up a walkthrough to help you out because while some quests are easy to do especially if you actually read what they want you to do, there are other quests where I just questioned Wtf am I supposed to do. Then when I do figure it out, I just think how tf was I supposed to know that. -Useless perks: There are some perks in this game that I took on my first playthrough that I thought would be good, only later to find out how useless they are and pretty much ruin my run. Traps and Gambling are prime examples of perks that you're rarely ever use most of the time. Watch out what you pick. You could really bone your run if you choose booty perks.Conclusion: This game may not be for everyone, but I urge you, stick with it. This is a kind of game I don't think we'll ever see today again. It's got laughs, it's got amazing writing, decent combat, some actual balls compared to newer fallouts (like being able to kill children and some of the subject matter) and it's just so damn interesting. Consider me a fallout 2 fan. This game rises as the best fallout game IMO.PS: Get the restoration project mod too! It adds cut content back into the game that makes the journey even cooler. (Just be sure to follow a guide for that too if you get stuck) :)

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Well this game is great.  I played this for much longer than Fallout 1 and there is reason for that.  This game has so much more content than the first.  There are many more quests and many more places to explore and visit.  This game is turning into one of my favorites because of everything the game is.  The guns are amazing to and all different.  What took the cake for this game was the dialouge and story.  The story far exeeds the first in depth and feel.  You feel like such a badass after the ending and feel satisfied.  The game is a memorable one for good reason.  What I didn't like about the game is that I wished that the Enclave were a better enemy faction.  I wish there were more to them so I can hate them more.  They did do things that were terrible to me but I didn't feel like they did much.  I guess that is the downside to isometric story driven games.  It is a great game and worth a buy.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												*For this game I will pretty much copy and paste my Fallout 1 review with a few changes, such as this game's world being larger and more content as well as the reputation system and Karma, other than that the game is pretty much the same as the first Fallout.*For those of you who got this game after playing 3, New Vegas and/or 4, prepare for a whole different cup of tea.This game is a isometric top down RPG(in case you didnt see the screenshots) and is a game that does not hold your hand whatsoever.And this being an older Fallout game means.....1) No tutorials and you are just thrown into the game straight.2) No quest markers meaning you might bang your head trying to find the correct location.3) You have to figure things out on your own.4) You have to save frequently lest you lose progress.5) Combat is significantly different that what you are used in future Fallouts, being slow and tactical.6) Inventory management and bartering is more cumbersome.7) Movement and exploration is slow with random encounters of random difficulty.If any of those turn you off then I suggest you rethink your purchase. Other than that, the game has a compelling story, great characters and quests to take on, its pretty much what you expect from the Fallout games, you are tasked with a huge responsibility and you set out to explore the wasteland. Its a very good game for its time and if you can get over the old game tropes I listed above, you are gonna have a good time.Now get out there and do your village proud Chosen One!!!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Fallout 2: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game. I have many fond memories of this game, it is one of my all time favorites and even after all these years, after all the hours and hours and hours I have put into the game across several different computers; I can still play it shamelessly for hours and never get bored. Its like a great film that you never tire of. I bought Fallout 2 back in '99, as a teen and could not stop playing it. I ended up becoming so engrossed in the game, that I took to the internet and found myself at the No Mutants Allowed forums where I started a long running RP called Fallout: Systematic Annihilation (My name was TRAG on those boards.) The RP was a little hit on the website, and we had quite a few fans that read it regularly and even joined in the fun. But, I didn't stop there- Chris Avellone started releasing a little document called- The Fallout Bible. I was pulled in yet again. I have read that Bible more than once- I even have a digital copy on my cell phone for my reading pleasure. Yeah, this game started an obsession. Thankfully, it never got bad enough to where restraining orders were necessary (This is a joke of course, but there are those out there that have gone that far). So, you have read how this game has touched my life, and inspired my imagination. Now, you are probably wondering- where is the review!?! Fallout 2 is an isometric post apocalyptic role playing game with turn-based combat. That being said, this is not just any isometric RPG, this is one of the most well written, deep, open world rpgs ever crafted. Your choices here carry real weight within the world- Want to be a Slaver? A rough, hard living slave catcher/seller. All you have to do is get a tattoo on your forehead that the world can see and you can be one. The only problem is that people really do see it and their reactions to you will reflect that. Needless to say, Slavers aren't exactly welcome in many places in the wasteland. You may wish to rethink that life choice. But, this game is not just about career choice, this is a game with a deep strategic combat system that will challenge even the most hardened RPG gamer. The game does not hold your hand and more than likely you will die a lot. Saving often is the best tool in your arsenal, and you will be relieved when you can reload your game only a few moments before you told that Super Mutant and his pals to shove it up his you know what, and instead he shoved it up yours...Lets move on.This is a CRPG in every sense of the word, so if you get the feel that there is a feeling that you could be playing this on a table with some friends and a cashe of multicolored dice, you probably could. In fact- There is a Pen and Paper version of the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system (the rules system the game is powered by.) on the internet and you can find it at No Mutants Allowed (the most well known Fallout fan site, find them here http://www.nma-fallout.com/ .) There is so much that I can say about this game, but I won't, because I believe that you owe it to yourself to see it with your own eyes.Fallout 2 is considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time for a reason: It lives up to the previous statement. It really is one of the greatest RPGs of all time. The writing is top notch, the sheer amount of choice and freedom. The methodical and satisfying development of your main character from an upstart, inexperienced tribal into a wasteland killing machine who is feared throughout the region, or a hero reveared by the struggling wasteland people. The choice is yours and your actions and decisions will determine the man/woman you become in this harsh and unforgiving post apocalyptic wasteland. You will need all the help you can get, and companions are there to meet and join your quest to restore your village and save its inhabitants from starvation, disease, and destruction.This game is so detailed for its time, that even today I am finding things I have never seen in the game before; and I have been playing it since 1999, a year after it was released! If that doesn't give you an idea of the replayability factor I don't know what will. If you purchase this game, you will come back to it year after year. And if you are a fan of pen and paper RPGS, CRPGS, or old school RPGs, then Fallout 2 is a godsend. Bigger and crazier than its predecessor Fallout (Which itself is an AMAZING game.) Fallout 2 takes you to the future that everyone hopes will never happen and lets you either wallow in it, or conquor it. I HIGHLY recommend this game for any RPG fan. It will ensnare you, it will inspire you!!

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Fallout 2, the successor to Fallout, a game that follows the apocalyptic aftermath of an alternate history where America, Asia and Europe have been subject to a nuclear resource war. In Fallout 2, the world is much larger and appropriately filled with interesting cities, towns, villages, and abandoned and occupied vaults. The story takes place after the actions of the Vault Dweller from Fallout, and many familiar faces will appear. There is, however, a new threat to the denizens of the wasteland. A powerful faction with advanced pre-war technology, who see the people of the irradiated wastes as monsters -- indistinguishable from ghouls and super mutants. Many new lively characters, stories, choices and weapons await in this great game.9/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												It's a good game, here is why.Pros:Reputations/karma/fame: e.g. you can become a slaver, which affects you in game, by making you despised by some of your possible companions.Cost: First of all, it's cheap, and for this reason alone I'd buy it. Bonus if you get it on sale.Gore: lots of it if you choose the bloody mess.Perks: lots of perks, depending on your actions and skills.Exploration: I felt as if exploring was fun and worth it.Funny: the humour is dark, which I prefer.Shortcuts: a lot of shortcuts, super useful.Cons:Story: the story is very fractured, and mostly involves you running around from A to B to C to D to kill 80 raiders then to finally get the GECK.Movement: the movement and combat are both very difficult to learn.Overall, I think it is fun and well made for its time, though frustrating at times.

The sequel to Fallout (1997); this game takes place 8 years after the first game following the same protagonist.The game mechanics are the same like the first game, but with NPC improvements.This storyline is set for you to save a village and explore new areas.If you liked the original Fallout game you'll still enjoy this one.7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2013
												Set roughly 80 years after Fallout 1, the world once again needs the aid of an individual to overcome a great evil. Originally you're sent out from your tribe, founded by the original Vault Dweller from F1, to retrieve a GECK that will help them survive as their village is dying. Needless to say, a lot more than that is going on which you will uncover soon enough.The world of Fallout 2 feels similliar to Fallout 1's (from here F1). The very south of F2's map is actually connected to F1's top, making it possible for the player to revisit a few of the old locations, such as Vault 13 and 15, as well as the NCR, which used to be Shady Sands. Other than that's there's a lot of new places to discover, including personal favorite of mine such as New Reno and a locationIreallycan'tnamewithoutspoilingthegame. As for the combat and levelling mechanics, these are the same as in F1, meaning you start the game by picking your SPECIAL and tag skills and as you defeat enemies in turn based combat and levelling up, you get to spend more skill points on various skills. The use of AP for moves in combat is a really neat system.As for F2 as a sequel, it's pretty great. The mechanics from F1 are re-used but other than that, it's a direct continuation on the lore with new events, a (mostly) new setting, all new story line and great characters.The massive downside of Fallout 2, however, is the start. The game starts in an insanely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial, and the first few hours are annoying as♥♥♥♥♥♥ The SPECIAL you pick at the start wil also really influence the game a *ton*. I, for example, went with 4 strenght, leaving me unable to use 90% of the weapons untill much later on, which was a major♥♥♥♥♥♥off. Amongst that the enemies suddenly go from easy to kill to pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ and if you're not prepared for that you're having a hard time. A good companion team is basically a must at that point.Before I wrap this up, I must say Fallout 2 has some absolutely hilarious moments to make up for some of the rage it might cause, such as the Café of Broken Dreams, the Bridge Guardian, conversations with certain NPCs and...SERGEANT DORNAN.Overall, 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												I was born two months premature. When I was one, I was dropped on the porch. When I was two, I had pneumonia. When I was three, I got the chicken pox. When I was four, I fell down the stairs and broke six ribs. When I was five, my uncle was decapitated by a watermelon. When I was six, my parents hit me in the head with a shovel. When I was seven, I lost my right index finger to my pet rat. When I was eight, my dog Spike got hit by a tractor. When I was nine, my mother lost her arm to a rabid brahmin. When I was ten, my sister was torn to bits by a pack of dogs. When I was eleven, my grandfather killed himself because I was ugly. When I was twelve, my grandmother killed herself because I was ugly. When I was thirteen, my father poked out his eyes with a pitchfork in a drunken stupor. When I was fourteen, my brother lost his hand to a wallaby. When I was fifteen, my aunt choked to death on a chicken bone. When I was sixteen, I lost my cousin to a badger. When I was seventeen, I cut off my left big toe with a hoe. When I was eighteen, my father lost his right leg to the same tractor that killed my dog.

The sequel to Fallout (1997); this game takes place 8 years after the first game following the same protagonist.The game mechanics are the same like the first game, but with NPC improvements.This storyline is set for you to save a village and explore new areas.If you liked the original Fallout game you'll still enjoy this one.7/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												It's a good game, here is why.Pros:Reputations/karma/fame: e.g. you can become a slaver, which affects you in game, by making you despised by some of your possible companions.Cost: First of all, it's cheap, and for this reason alone I'd buy it. Bonus if you get it on sale.Gore: lots of it if you choose the bloody mess.Perks: lots of perks, depending on your actions and skills.Exploration: I felt as if exploring was fun and worth it.Funny: the humour is dark, which I prefer.Shortcuts: a lot of shortcuts, super useful.Cons:Story: the story is very fractured, and mostly involves you running around from A to B to C to D to kill 80 raiders then to finally get the GECK.Movement: the movement and combat are both very difficult to learn.Overall, I think it is fun and well made for its time, though frustrating at times.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2012
												Fallout 2 - Fallout 2 is a direct sequel to Fallout 1; with only a year in between releases, not much has changed. The interface is fixed now, so it’s more in line with modern standards, but the combat is still freaking slow, so if you happen to choose non-combat skillsets, you are screwed. The graphic is improved which is pretty impressive given how little development time Interplay has between Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. As a result, innovation wasn’t present in this game at all. Players from Fallout 1 will notice a crap ton of game-breaking glitches being fixed in Fallout 2, you won’t get boxed in by friendly NPCs anymore because you can just push them away. The world is big(ger), and the plot is interesting as usual. Fair warning though, the game introduction is epically slow. Play Fallout 1 first, depending on how much you love that should help you determine if Fallout 2 is worth your time.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												I can't believe I haven't got round to writing a review for this game already!Fallout is a role playing game with an excellent story run throughout the series. This game is one of the best games I have ever played and it is a game that you can simply play through time and time again not only due to a wide range of choices but a story that you will want to hear again and again, admittedly the controls up until fallout 3 have been a bit primative and lack luster but they work if you're willing to give them a prod and experiment. Fallout 2 is an excellent addition to this series but the game either is for you or is not and with the excessive amount of bugs, primative style of controls and lacking graphics compared to todays top RPG's such as The elder scrolls I would only really reccomend this game is you really enjoyed fallout 3 and New vegas and would like to explore the story of fallout further; if you are one of those people who can't get enough of the fallout series this game is 100% for you, you will not be disappointed because the original games are just as good if not better than the recent ones except more primative.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												It was going well with this game at first. It's the typical story, you know? Girl meets game, game and girl fall in love, girl meets another game, game gets jealous...It was like, there was nothing to be jealous of, you know? I liked both games just the same, for different reasons, and I wasn't gonna forget about this game! But this game just didn't understand.We fought, we argued, and neither of us could remember what it was like to be in love with each other any more.And that's such a sad feeling- it's bad enough to fall out of love, but I'd say it's even worse to forget what love felt like in the first place. We said we'd still speak after the break up, but we lost contact.I guess I'd still recommend the game, but I have to warn you, if your relationship with the game hits a roadblock...You might fall out.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Black Isle at their finest.  Game is older than many gamers.  Reviewed ad nauseum, I will take this opportunity to impart an anecdote.I am currently playing thru this game.  I was getting annoyed at the engine.  Even 17 years ago, the hidden behind walls thing was mad annoying.  I have 1 full playthru, and many partials over that time, the last substantial one I stopped at New Reno.  That was 10 years ago.  I was in a town where there is an important NPC (skeeter) in a building that you can't see inside unless you run behind it.  The doors are on the hidden backside.  I knew as I played before, but was a little frustrated.  I was muttering about how Pillars better have screen rotation.  Then I randomly talked to an npc behind this building a bit.  This one was in view.  I asked about the other guy who is hidden a few steps away, and the NPC says "he's standing right there.  Use your eyes."  Those guys at Black Isle knew full well how frustrating not being able to see an npc standing 10 feet away right in front of you due to an immobile painted background, and put those lines in there.  I bet whoever wrote that bit snickered like I did.  I never read those lines before, in probably 100 hours of varied gameplay.  The nuance and subtlety is what is so great about this game.  The way characters are written, the storylines, and unsanitary reality of what harsh life does to mankind.  The good do indeed die young as even the good ones have some bad in this world.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												Fallout 2 ReviewIs it still great all these years down the line?Pros:Solid gameplayWider variety of weapons over Fallout 1More locations than Fallout 1LOTS more companionsMore intresting charactersTalking HeadsActive modding community (mods still being made at the time of writing)You can have a robo-dogYou can team-up with a... Well, you'll know once you get to it. Wouldn't want to spoil a nice suprise :)Loads of contentConsThere's a bit of stuff I consider uneccessary. New Reno as a whole is... Well really designed for fan service. There's a brothel and a porn studio here. When you have entire PERKS centered around sex, you know something is wrong.Progression in the beginning is slowGeckos. Screw these things. Especially at the start.Missing content that's easily replaced with Fallout 2 Restoration mods.Getting a gun that isn't a pea shooter takes FOREVER. Prices are INSANELY high after Fallout 1. I mean, REALLY high. At the start, it cost me my entire supply of money, a gun I previously had (which was an EVEN WORSE pea shooter) and whatever I could scrounge up from the houses near by to get a 10MM pistol. Still a pea shooter, but it dealt more damage.Random encounters are FAR too frequent. It's frustrating when the second you leave the city you're attacked by tweleve dogs, and it takes a few minutes for them to end their turn. And you can't run because they've trapped you.Relies too heavily on pop-culture refrences that are now outdated. Funny at the time, but in 2015, some don't make sense or some are just plain stupid.On the whole, Fallout 2 is a game everyone who can think should own. This isn't a game for people that played 3 and New Vegas and enjoyed the shooter aspects: This is a bare knuckle, hard core RPG, and you WILL die. Many many times.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												To be frank, I really enjoyed the game. I started playing it way after it was released, so this isn't a nostalgia trip for me or anything, this was from pure interest in the genre and what I've heard about it. I was not disappointed.This game is packed with content. There's lots of quests, characters, weapons, locations, and items. There's almost always 2 or 3 ways to resolve a conflict and the straightest path isn't always the best one. Most of your choices do have some sort of consequence. The combat can be pretty challenging, but can also be like super easy if you have the right build, it's not particularly well balanced. The visuals, well, they kind of hit the spot for what the game is portraying. Dark, dull, forboding, if not boring landscapes. I mean, you're in the middle of the desert, it's not that interesting. The humor is pretty cool, and I must have laughed a few times at either something happening or when a character said something funny. The story is pretty interesting overall, having you start as one of the previous PC's (from Fallout) decendants in a tribal community to helping out (or hurting) towns or refugees to disabling (or enabling) nukes.I think that anyone who can deal with turn-based rpgs should play this. It's pretty awesome. Even if you haven't played turn-based rpgs or maybe have had bad experiences with them, you should like this. But stay away if you can only handle fps style gameplay, this isn't for you.The steam version does work with all of the mods out there btw, I've not run into any issues regarding that stuff.10/10Would die in the first battle again.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Simply put Fallout 2 is a masterpiece. It improves upon Fallout 1 in virtually every way and it allows for such creative roleplaying and variety that I am still impressed that few games have surpassed this. You might want to be a slaver one playthrough and a pornstar the next who is also a champion boxer. What more do you want? Well if you want good companions you're in luck because Fallout 2 has the best companions in the whole series and they're not even comparable to the cardboard cutouts in Fallout 1.Superficially this looks just like Fallout 1 but more (the same opinion people had for New Vegas compared to 3) but the more you play it the more you realise it stands out as a wonderful game in its own right, not just as a sequel to another amazing CRPG.I'll admit that out of the 3 amazing Fallouts (1, 2 and New Vegas) this has my least favourite main quest and the final showdown is only a fraction as good as the confrontation with the Master. But despite all that Fallout 2 is an amazing game with few faults.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												(Note: Bought this game elsewhere, but wanted a digital version)The sequal to the fantastic Fallout game, you know you are in good hands. This game is set years after the first where you play as a decendent of the Vault Dweller who has been tasked to go out and find the vault for it may contain a G.E.C.K (Garden of Eden Creation Kit) which could save your people as many are sick and dying as are there Brahman. You start by proving your worth by entering the temple of the vault dweller and retriving the vault 13 suit left by your ancestor before heading out for the elusive Vault 13.This game is far better than the previous by doing away with the timer that was in the first one, however the start does involve you running into giant ants and lesser radscorpions in the temple and being armed with only a spear so if you focus on gunpower, there's a good chance you might die or be unable to get through the temple. This game also has the introduction to power gloves if you wish to make a mellee focused character where no previous such weapon exsisted in the first and you were stuck otherwise. There is more adult subject matter as you get to sleep with numerous women (or men depending on sex or your choice) with only a brief description which is somehow more graphic than the Bethesda attempt (dissapointing since the game is a 18, you'd think you'd be treated as a adult) but that's a different discussion for something else.For those who have played Fallout 3, this game is where the Enclave first appeared and in this you run into references to the previous game (appearance of Harold, a discovery of a horde of water chips and a Super mutant who is worried about getting a woman pregnant) as well as an evolution in the society where no longer do people collect bottle caps, but crudly made discs called Dollars.  Ghouls and Super Mutants are no longer a big enemy as they have been trying to intergrate with society (except for Vault City which is Xenophobic) and even gain a Super Mutant as a companion as well as many other interesting and even hidden companions.Well worth if you enjoyed the first game and a lot of fun if you like RPGs in general. You don't need to have played the first one as you can always ask questions about why the world is the way it is and the story has a totally different enemy than the last one. You also have multiple possible endings when you complete the game like the previous one and get to see how Shady Sands has evolved into the infamous NCR.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is the Fallout franchise at its peak.  Taking the open world of a post-apocalyptic wasteland of the original and making it 10+ times bigger but keeping the charm of almost every location that you visit.  Every location is detailed and contains a bevy of unique and interesting characters.  This was in the era of audio dialogue and coupled with the computer generated faces of a range of notable characters from the story made this game very engulfing (except Myron, ♥♥♥♥ THAT GUY).  Add to that a list of amazing voice actors that fit their roles like a glove.  Before we got the idiotic Karma system of Fallout 3 (who is thinking of 'karma' in a dog-eat-dog wasteland?), we had the awesome system of reputation for each location (this was the influence for the faction rep in New Vegas) and it worked wonderfully.  I only wish that we could have experienced the original vision of Fallout 3 (Van Buren) instead of the Bethesda, barely-working abortion of Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: March 27
												Bizarre is a word that comes to mind when playing Fallout 2. Its a world both serious and very silly at the same time. The main quest is serious but the whole game is full of pop culture references and silly scenes, sex and drugs run rampant and it feel like almost everyone is a sneeze away from wanting to kill you.  I know this game is treated like a religion so people are going to hate me but I'm being honest despite the fact how someone can downvote this game while ignoring all peer pressure and being honest lol. I Installed a restoration patch which added many things although I was there mainly for bug fixes. My strange story included giving children an orphanage to get them off the streets, sleeping with a mob leaders wife while dealing with mobster wars in an even more lawless city, getting someones spleen back which he lost in a bet, moving a plant to another garden so he could teach me how to beat a Radscorpion at chess and many many more but mostly just shooting annoying obnoxious people in the face. The combat is pretty much the same as Fallout 1 and for me that is no bad thing with a few new weapons added andthe gory deaths are still here. I encountered many things in the world map such as knights looking for a holy hand grenade then right after meeting them again getting killed by a small rat despite their power armor, Darth Vadar and friends standing around chatting while Han Solo told me something there no match for a good blaster so gave me a blaster, a crashed ship with dead red shirts, a dead whale in the middle of the desert and a man guarding a bridge asking familiar questions, the Cafe of Broken Dreams and many more which you will probably recognise. Amongst the things I didn't like is Fallout 2 has many quests but alot of them are not obvious and this game needs a guide/walkthough more than most as many are at least semi hidden and even when you get them there is no reminder in your log where you had to go/do what. Such things will effect new players more and it can be and get very confusing especially amongst its bloated game world. The same with items, there is no description how things work and what they do such as drugs and medical items and which items are just vendor trash. Once again this effects new players more because once you know you remember but there is no harm with an ingame description but I do understand games were different when this was made. With NPC's too Its so easy to say '' the wrong thing '' which more so than Fallout 1 can suddenly turn even whole towns hostile and likely result in a last save game reload. Skill checks are still here but like Fallout 1 they are '' invisible '' so you may not know when you are using them. This game is also difficult , more so than Fallout 1 and companions are almost as annoying. Comparing to the later fallout games is hard because like the Fallout 1 they are so different especially the obvious Isometric vs First Person game worlds. Having said that Fallout 2 does feel very different to Fallout 1 in many ways too. I noticed when watching Bethesda's '' making of Fallout 3 video '' they would reference Fallout 1 but not Fallout 2 so I guess they had that more in mind. Overall I can see why people like this game and while I like easter eggs and the occasional joke this game takes things beyond silly so much which felt too distracting. Also I cannot be like one of those people who are like '' wow you can bea porn star 10/10 game'' . I spent along time experiencing what this game offers which I don't regret but honestly I prefer Fallout 1 as The story , atmosphere and locations feel more consistent and the lol sillyness is not everywhere you go. I did prefer certain things in Fallout 2 such as better inventory management, the car for faster transport (which is needed in this bigger map) and you can store items in and unlike Fallout 4 the characters are not making excuses to explain indepth or technical things for you. Not a terrible game if you can get over the archaic game design. Still try it for yourself you may like it like many others seem to and you can get it quite cheap these days in sales.

												Fallout 2 is one of the best PC RPGs of all time.  I do think Fallout: New Vegas is the best Fallout game, but out of the original 3 (Fallout 1, Fallout 2, and Tactics) this is the best.  I do recomend that you play Fallout 1 first though, gives you a better insight into the world.  Unlike the first one, that had a time limit, this one lets you♥♥♥♥♥♥around from the start.  You can do lots of cool things, like be a porn star, drive a car, and blow up the U.S government. I will worn you though, this is an old game.  The graphics haven't aged too well.  Also, the technology couldn't display hightech things, so you'll see a lot of repeat charicter models. Also, the game has a bird's eye view, so if that is not something you like, then get over it because this is one of the best RPGs ever. Buy it now!

												The sequel to the original Fallout (which is fantastic, by the way) this is quite possibly the best installment of the Fallout franchise. It still has the strategic isometric turn-based combat, and not much has changed from the original in terms of the controls department. It's still gloriously simple, but be warned that if you're not particularly high in Strength with either a decent unarmed or melee skill, you're gonna have a bad time in the beginning. An extremely rich storyline, hours upon hours of complex gameplay, and a talking Deathclaw in your party.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game acts a very good blend of First person shooter and stealth into the game as you are thrown into an enviroment that is very breath taking. It has everything a gamer could ever dream of including dinosaurs, tanks, zombies, and wizards. The textures are in 1080p and is the most amazing thing i have ever seen and the ominous atmosphere just makes my heart race as i try to find the nearest telephone booth. The amount of effect put into this game by the developer is just truly in need of an applause as they have spent near decades of working the game to the brim with content and the amount of detail into everything in the game is great. The fully animated 3d polygons are a true work of art. The replayability is just unreal as i spent several decades dedication my life into making new characters and roleplaying as one of the many NPC in this game. It also introduces Enviroments that are mindblowing as you wouldnt think they would inploment it in here. I spent most of my time looking inside every cave, forest, town i explored to uncover secrets yet to be told. The mechanics of this FPS rivals those of Call of duty  and needs more recognition. and in conclusion i have no idea what i am talking about.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												The controls aren't initially too bad, especially when you finally master them. Unfortunately, Black Isle Studios didn't have the knack to implement an abundance of voice actors. Truth be told there are only a handful of them in the entire game. Everything else is good old fashion dialogue. Sure, you might here me and other people complain about this. But let's just say, for the shake of this review. I get over the fact the game only has a limited amount of voice actors until Fallout 3. The only major problem I've encountered thus far with Fallout 1 through 2 (including Fallout Tactics) is the despicable combat system. I mean this combat system sucks.. I'm talking atari style combat.. A friendly individual fires first, then a hostile target fires second. It essentially goes back and fourth until one or the other is dead. This is extremely unrealistic, and truthfully. I don't believe there was any excuse for this whatsoever. Take my word for it, I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series; but this is just ridiculous. In closing this message, I want to add the story is of course outstanding. I hope one day they'll consider doing a remastered version of both Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Preferably with Fallout 4's new creation engine.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												Admission time: I didn't get into Fallout until 3... and I don't like the older ones.It's not the visuals - I'm a huge fan of Baldur's Gate and Divine Divinity, which it resembles from a visual perspective. It's fine, if not impressive.It's not the writing. The word is definately Fallout, and it's awesome. So... here's the problem...IT'S SOOOOOOOO SLOW.It's maddening. I really, really want to get into it, and explore the world, and delve into the earlier fallout games. I want to watch the step-by-step creation of a thing I love. I did the same thing for Saint's Row, and while 1&2 are pretty rough around the edges, they're still perfectly good games. Fallout 1&2? Yeah, not so much. I'm not spoiled, I'm not too "modern" a gamer. I love turn based strategy games. I only want the visuals to be appropriate and not hideous, and these are well within that criteria. But the interface is awkward, even taking into account the age of the game. The action is so slow that it's hard to call action...And all of that keeps me from enjoying the rest of the game - which, I'm told, is awesome. It could be the best game ever, but I can't bear playing it through the initial quest, so I'll never know. If you've got the patience of Job, I imagine you'll love it. If I hadn't played the Baldur's Gate games - which use the same engine, but move at a steady clip - I might love it, too... but holy crap, I just can't bear the awkward coupled with the slow.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Plainly put: This game is bad.I have a number of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ anecdotes that came from the tiny six hour window I played this game in, and numberous small complaints. Being able to sell quest items so you trudge all over the ♥♥♥♥ing wastes looking for♥♥♥♥♥♥only to find out you'd sold it an hour later. No ♥♥♥♥ing idea what you're doing in the temple so you have to ♥♥♥♥ around with walkthroughs just to learn the basic mechanics. Random encounters when you're level 2 where you get torn to pieces by mole rats. Wanting to try to do something with the skills you can barely use, but not knowing if you can't do it or if the game is giving you a "trolled ya! ;)" moment. Fallout 2 is old and it really, REALLY shows. This game is a slog. The combat most especially- most of my fights involved both me and the enemy missing at least ten times in a row on a regular basis, and it wore my patience so thin that I would prefer running away to fighting enemies because that♥♥♥♥♥♥is grueling. The story, through the shreds I got, wasn't interesting enough or presented well enough for me to really give this more than the six hour shot I did. When I booted up Fallout 2 in an attempt to desperately get some enjoyment out of the game, it was a ♥♥♥♥ing chore to play and I kept thinking of all the other♥♥♥♥♥♥I could be doing. Graphics are... Alright, I guess? They're old. The lack of sound / songs in the game was driving me insane, though, and I ended up just putting on a playlist of old Bob Crosby / Jo Stafford / Pied Piper songs in order to force myself through it. I know they probably couldn't license any songs because at that point it was a tiny little studio, but it was a surprisingly huge letdown coming off the back of the FPS Fallouts and I get the feeling you'd only enjoy this soundless, lifeless wasteland if you were there when it came out.Just go play New Vegas. Or Fallout 3. Or, ♥♥♥♥, even 4 was a lot better. Comparing them is like comparing apples to steak, because they're totally different in terms of gameplay and presentation, but holy ♥♥♥♥ this game has aged like spoiled milk. Don't buy it, and with the money you were going to use to buy it, go buy Vegas. Same area(ish), good game. Just watch a gameplay video or read the Fallout Wiki if you need to know the story of 1 and 2, because if you're going back to 2 from the modern fallouts it's going to hurt.

												I've heard that Fallout 2 is an amazing RPG and as much as I would like to believe that it just feels like a snoozefest. The beggining of the game is extremely slow and the movement is excruciating, i've finished the first fallout and despite it also being slow-paced it was manageable. As much as I like games to challenge the user and not hold the consumer's hand, I feel fallout 2 (and this is another complaint I had with Fallout 1) just expects you to know where to go for quests and as much as I like adventure and exploring it simply isn't fast paced or accessible enough for that function.  I'm also not very keen on games that use RNG as it doesn't actually require much skill but instead luck and preparation. I might come back to Fallout 2 but atm I just feel that there are plenty of other games to play that will keep me engaged and I never play games just for the sake of it, I have to enjoy them.

number of helpful: 14 of 62 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
Haven't played Fallout and Fallout 2 until now? Better keep it that way.EDIT: I encourage everyone, who fiercely downvotes my review, to try and argue against any of the points I make.I won't be denying the importance and fun factor these games had once upon a time, but unless you're already wearing thick nostalgia-goggles, these titles sadly are not worth playing today. The one redeeming factor of these games is the lore contained within their plethora of content. Indeed, you can easily spend hundreds of hours in their captivating world and still have occasionally some fun. However, far too many aspects of the early Fallout entries are either extremely sloppy, ill-conceived or altogether broken. Below are the main reasons why I got so turned off: Frequent crashes - both games (especially Fallout 1) like to crash a lot. I'd understand if it was caused by the games' age and poor compatibility with modern Windows, but as I found out, the same error messages were just as common back then, as they are now.  Frequent glitches - perhaps I'm like a magnet attracting various anomalies, but I can't be impressed by standing dead bodies and NPCs walking through closed doors and walls. Disappearing coursor is quite possibly one of the most annoying bugs I've encountered so far.  Either absolutely tedious or extremely irritating combat - Despite the slow pace, I usually like turn based combat in games, because it puts emphasis on strategy, rather than reflexes. Fallout 1 and 2, sadly, highlight the sluggishness while happily ditching all the strategy. You control only your own character at all times. Your occasional companions are just extremely r*tarded AIs, that are about as likely to shoot your enemies, as they're to shoot you in the back by mistake. The single worst thing about the combat for me is the very system of calculations upon which it is built. Never in my life, have I seen in-game battles as random as those in Fallout. I've experienced the same type of damage, going from the same source, hover between "no damage inflicted" (thanks to my damage resistance) all the way to more than 300 points of damage - a nearly quadruple of my total HP count at that point. To amplify the randomness even more, combatants can have "critical failures", which is just an awful idea from the get-go, because it makes them look like totally incompetent buffoons. The worst UI I have ever dealt with - Every minute of me dealing with the "inventory" makes me feel ten years older. How this UI system got ever approved baffles me. The worst kind of today console port feels like a breeze to deal with next to Fallout's inventory. The game is capable of giving you a finger after tens of hours playing it - At least that's how I felt once I discovered, that the skills I picked during the character creation were totally worthless. I thought I'd try to play as a character that would be throwing stuff in combat (just to make things a tad more interesting) and using melee, which worked out okay up to certain point. Then I realised I've been using the same effing spear since the very beginning and that my character slowly, but surely, becomes completely unusable in combat against all the assault-rifles, combat shotguns etc. I was unable to find any better melee weapon until a lot later, making my melee irrelevant for the whole mid-game.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												So after playing this game for 50 hours, I find myself in a position whereby I'm unable to complete the game. I've spent hours reading various walkthroughs and forums to try and figure out why this is and it seems that the main quest, obviously the most important in the game, is a convoluted, buggy mess whereby actions you take will have completely unforseen consequences that will essentially make the game unwinnable.This is a game that people praise for it's open-ended structure and freedom and yet even in the main quest it will punish you from deviating even slightly from the prescribed path.This by itself would be enough for me to not recommend this game but it also has a number of other problems. The AI is terrible and your followers will shoot you if you're stood between them and a target as well as regularly blocking doorways. The user interface is absolutely terrible. Simple things like inventory management and issuing orders to your followers are a complete chore. The mission tracker is literally a single, short line of text. If you forget exactly what you have to do next, you're screwed.This game has not stood the test of time.

number of helpful: 12 of 72 people (17%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												I played this game when it first came out.  I thought it was awsome, and in its time, it was.However, times change.  After playing it a bit, I have found that I do not have patience for old-school game mechanics.For example: You get a quest to Find X.  X can be a person, or an object.  And that is all you get.  Please find X and get something from him.  You would think getting the object from Mr. X would be the problem and perhaps you are right.  However, you must spend HOURS clicking on everyone in town to find Mr. X, IF HE IS EVEN IN THAT SAME town.  If it is an object, lets hope you notice it amonge the muddled brown textures sitting on the ground somewhere.Do you want to recall what NPC said about something, perhaps there is a hint in something he or she said?  You will not find any such notes in your trusty pip boy.  Perhaps you can find the NPC and talk to them again.  Maybe they will go through thier dialog again, or perhaps they will just ask you if you got the job done yet and you will be SOL.Anyway, I discovered I do not have the patience for such things anymore.  If you do, then this game is a great classic.  Just be sure you are in the mood to play a very long, old school game or are ok with constantly googling the quest solutions.

number of helpful: 7 of 55 people (13%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												The game is mainly a hex-based, turn-based combat system with "Action points" determining what you can and can't do.  The "S.P.E.C.I.A.L" leveling system is there and will also determine what you can and can't do in game. ( Playing with Intelligence less than 4 you can't even speak properly and NPC's will even ignore you or not give you quests )  Just like most RPG's of the era the beginning game is a hard survival but as it gets to approx mid-game money becomes so plentiful and your skills advance so quickly that most challenges are cleared easily.  This game features a car for you to drive around the wasteland quicker than normal and can be upgraded slightly for better fuel consumption, etc. It does, however run on the same ammunition as energy pistols / rifles.  It can also be used as a storage container but beware a bug where too many things are inside it, you'll get locked out of the menu. It also seats all your followers which is a nice added feature. Speaking of followers, they're still the same stupid things that block every-bloody-entranceway when you walk into a room. However they've put a helpful "Shove" Icon in which pushes the follower one hex away, they've also added extra combat controls ( Although default is usually best for pretty much all situations ) that come in Beserker, aggressive, defensive and custom. The ability to choose which armour they wear, although there is no visable change and the ability to get them to use a selection of weapons ( Although they can only use certain weapons, not any weapon as Followers are only "loaded" with certain animations )However I cannot recommend this game solely on the basis that it is so buggy and frustraiting. Walk into the wrong part of town at the wrong time of day and all the guards shoot at you. Enemies ignore you if you wear a certain armour type but if you have a follower in the same armour only 1 type of enemy will shoot you, yet if you walk into a town with your parties weapons drawn everyone will shoot you.It's highly inconsistant and irritaiting, saving everytime you do something successfully becomes regular. The game only received one patch in it's life and like many others have said, you have to mod the game for it to become bareable. So likening this over Fallout 4 but then telling people you need mods to enjoy Fallout 1 or 2 is hypocritical.It's a shame because I got it as part of the Fallout Anthology and I haven't enjoyed either game and I cannot really see why it has such a cult following. Even other RPG's of the time period this was launched fare better and I think being the one of the only post-apocolyptic and non-fantasy based RPG got it where it is.

												This highly-regarded classic game has the worst introduction/tutorial imaginable. A journey through a temple teaches the player some of the basic mechanics of the game by boring them to death. I've purchased some classic games this month: Heroes of Might and Magic 3, System Shock 2, and Fallout 2. Heroes is every bit as awesome today as it was 20 years ago. SS2 is nowhere near as scary as I remember and  now it feels like its just a series of switch flipping missions to advance to the next area; level design has IMPROVED. This game, Fallout 2, is the worst of the three, by far. It is no longer fun to have only a 19% chance to hit an ant thats directly in front of you; was it fun 20 years ago? Must have been since thousands of people got past the tutorial...Not me.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												This game has not aged well. If you are commited or have played this game or games like it in the past, you will have fun. If you are a young and naive Fallout fan who played 3 and New Vegas and are looking for a new adventure, this game is not for you. It plays nothing like 3 and New Vegas. It's a top down RPG and it plays like one. It's difficult, there's a lot of reading, and most of the game mechanics feel like they died during the clinton administration. My point is the game is old. There's no getting around it. If I or You don't like this game, it doesn't mean that I/you are not a fallout fan. It's an old game, it doesn't mean it has to be good/bad. In conclusion, the game hasn't aged well. It's old and plays like an old game. You also may have trouble running it on your computer.

content:

												I had found out about fallout in 2008 when fallout 3 first came out. I instantly fell in love with everything about the game, i hadnt even heard of the fallout series before this. Keep in mind im now 30 and have long expressed interest in RPG games so how did the first two games fall under my nose? Well rhetorical or not they did, and finally...finally after hours of reading the reviews of how its the best rpg ever and so so so much better than fallout 3 I bought it.And I must say I am quite dissapointed! The fighting is just so mundane and repetitive...It took me 3 mins to kill a rat! Miss after miss after miss it was just stupid.The inventory....So untidy, just full of everything making me point and click to see even what the hell it is.One of my favorite parts of fallout 3 is organizing all my items and rumaging through every single desk, cabinet and safe. WELL NOT ANYMORE. It is just so tedious making my character check all this stuff, pointing and clicking till my fingers fall out.Keep in mind im 30 and have been playing games like starcraft, AOE, diablo etc for a long time so I love to click but this is too much for too little reward. I cant believe id say this about a fallout game but I got maybe fours into it and i think im just finished playing it. It doesnt give me that "addiction" mentality to warrant putting those true kinds of hours into it.I suppose I would of loved it perhaps if I played it 15 years ago when it came out...wait...thats exactly it! why am i even writing this review...?!and to be honest I dont even want fallout 4 to come out, its taken so much of my life I love playing it but...at what cost??

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												As a hardcore RPG veteran, I'm telling you that this game is not like Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment, an Elder Scrolls game, or any other classic you might like. If you're looking for something similar to one of those (like I was), don't buy Fallout 2.I've tried nurmerous times to like Fallout 2. But each time it just utterly frustrates me.Fallout 1 is a great game because of the dozens of ways you can build a character. In fact, it's not that hard to beat the game as a pacifist, relying on skills and such instead of fighting. It offers a true roleplaying experience and rewards creativity. It lets you roleplay the character that you want. Fallout 2 is the opposite. It is based way too heavily on combat. Even on low difficulties, the fights are really hard. In addition, there are random encounters that happen while fast-traveling, that in addition to be very annoying and repetitive, also contribute to this difficulty problem. You basically get fatally punished for not making a perfect charatcer, and for exploring. The lattter of which defeats the purpose of an open-world game. Playing a character that is focused around dealing with problems by using things like stealth, speech, or computers is impossible. Only heavily combat oriented characters can survive. But even if you optimize a character for combat, it's still ridiculously hard. I did exactly that (optimizing for combat) and still got 1-hit-killed by a gecko on easy after barely leaving the starting area, so I'm not exactly sure what kind of build is capable of beating this game.Apparently, you can only play the developer's way rather than playing how you want to play. By not letting you play the ROLE you want, it completely defeats the purpose of ROLE PLAYING. And since it isn't fun and feels more like work, it isn't really a game.So in conclusion, Fallout 2 neither role playing, nor is it a game.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
"What is the definition of insanity? Doing the exact same thing, whilst expecting different results."Save/Load fest that is an impossibility without a guide, filled to the brim with below-the-belt humor and obscure, awkward cultural references and puzzling non-sequiturs. Possibly one of the worst games ever made. In 23 years of gaming there are very few games to which I can come back to, after years, and still feel an outrage 15 minutes into the "gameplay".This game is just ridiculously bad, it's horrendous. It's a mystery how you could ♥♥♥♥ up something as good as Fallout 1 so badly. A munchkin heaven. Grind to survive - for hours. This is why people play things like WoW - no proper aim in the game, just a mindless levelling and math stats enough to get you through Calculus exam, made up of puree of elements from previous installment, sprewn across the blanket of an aged engine.Needless skill increases that you would only need to use once like lockpick to open only one rusty door which does not get damaged explosives or crowbars (or anything else). Or repair at ridiculous level of 50% to repair a generator to progress further in the quest.The quests are illogical, game elements are not standardised (one door can be broken with a crowbar, another with a fist, another one is barely held together, but can easily take on a C4 or a plasma shot). You have to find "extravagant solutions" but your freedom is not limited by your own imagination, it's limited by twisted imagination of neckbeard developers.Weapons and elements that are completely unrelated to Fallout universe are shoved in, like they are shoved in later in NV (the "Service Rifle" and shiny nuAge "9mm" as opposed to proper aged 50's sci-fi weapons of Fal 1 and Fal 3) completely screwing up the whole immersion.300% for skills, why not 500? ♥♥♥♥ it, why not 1000? And a perk only every 50 levels instead of every 2-3.How 'bout missing a 90% chance to hit in a row, thrice or four times while getting always hit by early-game enemies from three screens away? How about random encounters every 5 minutes with packs of wolves and dozens upon dozens of raiders with weapons that crit. hit you every single time?How about bugged out everything, from the dialogues with followers where you're unable to trade or to take their equipment to the glitches and crashes. I have nearly completed this pile of dogshit until the game crashed and corrupted THREE of my saves in the Navarro base, I had to go back to my saves more than a decade of levels ago when I was just making it big in the ♥♥♥♥ing New Reno.Near infinite ammo for enemies, inability to steal it before the fight.Stupidly overpowered enemy armour, lack of critical hits even for luck 10.The game is stupidly, mindbogginly, grindingly difficult for no other reason than "because ♥♥♥♥ you!", it was created simply for those who thought Fallout 1 was not enough, but it was. It was more than enough.Ludicrously nerfed unarmed combat. A punch with spiked knuckles that does 4 damage at over 140% Unarmed? Really? 4 attacks per turn for most enemies in HtH? Late acquisition of Bonus HtH attacks perk? Dogs and Rats that do 8 damage (non-critical!) to an upgraded leather armour? Early raiders that never miss a burst and do over 70 damage per an always critical hit? Dumbass Cassidy that always misses the enemy and hits me? Use Jet once - you're an addict? Knuckles do more damage than a power fist? Come on! Incredibly narrow focus on select skills, while others are of no use. You want to play a character of your own? Tough♥♥♥♥♥♥ pick guns and speech, otherwise you're gonna have a bad time.Walls of text, boring dialogues that reek of grade 9 English literature homework and bunch of other irrelevant stuff that just breaks the experience. Ghosts, friendly mutants and talking deathclaws... what? The game is either trying to be too serious or too wacky. Racial stereotypes and biased, black and white, presentation of the world. New Reno, for example, is supposed to be the "cool place with no morally polar characters" as it's everything that's "bad" in humanity, filled with vice and rotten people. But it's a sarcasm that misses its mark because it's so "ad absurdum" and gortesque - the actual essence of it is unrealistic and this distances the player from the game. Everything feels like a joke and yet the game is taking itself seriously, like a comedian that's gone too far into the number as the nervous audience chuckle to avoid awkwardness of the moment.At level 10 the pack of wolves is still a problem. A bodyguard in a casino get's a face full of Minigun at Big Guns 120+ % to get 12 damage and comes back with 30 damage as you get gunned down by a simple shotgun shot half the way across the room.And to top everything off, constant crashes, corrupt game save files and tons of bugs.It feels like a DLC to the great Fallout. Dumbed down and with ridiculous traits like "childkiller" and such.No wonder it was more popular than the original, YOBA approved.Worse than Fallout 1 in all respects except one - inventory management.I come back to this..."game" every once in a while, mustering all of my will just to push down the stomach convulsions as I try to keep myself from vomiting or just trashing my computer and putting a wooden stake into its remains so that "it would not rise to terrify the living ever again". And every time I do, I honestly try to enjoy it and beat it, but the truth is, this is the only game that I cannot bring myself to tolerate. No matter how much time has passed since my previous attempt, be it late 90's or today. A steaming pile of rotten ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ does not turn into a fruitcake and some things only get worse with time.Horrible.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												I have to admit that I never played either of the original Fallout games back when they first came out and only became aware of the series during the release of Fallout 3 which I fell in love with. To say I was hesitant in getting into an older game that is known for being arduously difficult and based on the GURPS RPG system is a gods damned understatement. But when that good ol' Steam Holiday sale rolled by and saw this game for the dirt cheap, I decided "What the ♥♥♥♥" and started my new favorite game.Folks without a doubt this is a great game. Its fun, its got great writing, the gameplay mechanics (though challenging at first if unfamiliar) are great, the character system is great...the game is ♥♥♥♥ing great. Obviously, however, it's not perfect. For starters its graphics have aged with the grace of an avacado left under a UV lamp in high humidity for several decades and can prove to be frustrating when you initially start the game and everything looks horribly glitched until you find a fix it. Pacing can be hard to get into if you go from a fast paced pick up and play game, and there is a lot of reading (which isn't a negative but for extensive gaming it can ware your eyes sore).While it is true that you can basically make a perfect character based on how you want to play the game (ex. a character perfect for the main campaign invest stats in X,X,X an X etc.,) the fun of this game is just seeing what happens when you try and not be conventional. This is where the GURPS mechanic shines and as a result I'm looking into the table top game system  . This game is fun to play around in and while, yes trial and error results in several (and I mean SEVERAL) in game deaths for the uninitiated, it helps you get a strong feel for the world you are playing in.Another minor gripe I have is that there is no tutorial, you are basically dropped into the game and left to figure it out, which for some is great, but it would have been nice to have the option.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												Fallout 2, what can I say about this glorious game... it's easily the best rpg of it's time. Even today it's one of the few games I can go back to and play endlessly. I probably have closer to 250 hours in at the time of this review. I played it on an old laptop before I got steam. It is without a doubt the best turn based rpg I have ever play and the only thing that comes close is fallout 1. If you are in anyway interested in the begining of fallout you should no doubt get this game. If you want to try out a good retro or classic game look no further. If you are concerned about graphical glitches people seem to be having it's because the colors are 8-bit. Go to Killap.net and download the restoration installer. I man spent years recovering all cut content and patching almost all known issues in the game. It greatly expands content fixes almost all issues and gives resolution options and color bit choices. Fallout 2 is a timeless game that will forever be the pinnacle of classic rpgs. I would spend more time telling you what I love about the game but I would have to describe every aspect of the game. The only thing lacking is actually radiation. There is not much of it for a game about fallout lol. Other than that it's perfect 10 out of 10.
