Posted: August 3, 2014
												Well, my relationship with the fallout series isn't that lengthy, as I have still yet to complete Fallout and Fallout Tactics along with all the other classic Fallout games. But as a person who mainly just favors FPS and direct combat and whatnot, when I first got this game, I was plagued with graphics issues.Things showing up as mixmatch of black,red,blue pixels, overall sound being rather screwed up, and I really started to doubt whether my purchase was worth it.But recently, while waiting at an airport, I decided to just out of boredom give this game a try.I dunno what really happened, but the graphics problem was gone. I assume it was patched over the time that I left it to sit in the library, but it was gone. I watched the intro, I started to play, and there I was, clicking away for hours.This sort of game with the old-school PC point and click action normally wouldn't be my cup of soup, but for whatever reason this game got me addicted. I paid more attention to story than I ever did with Fallout 3 and New Vegas, and even just laughed at how many cultural references were being made in this game, along with certain 4th wall breaking elements.Basic story line goes like this. You are a tribal who leaves your settlement to find a GECK, which is supposed to turn barren land into fertile soil, and recreate towns. You go on a looooooong journey, choosing careers, finding companions, but once you come back to your village, you find out that it's been removed, and the lone survivor tells you to go and find them.The rest is up to you to find out. No more spoilers for you, come back next year!Did I mention careers? Hell, there are also so many reputations/jobs/statuses you can get. Do you want to be a gun-slinging ganster? Do you want to be a dirt-flinging grave digger? Do you want to be a crap-shoveling brahmin excrement remover? Do you want to be a♥♥♥♥♥♥swinging pornstar? Do you want to get MARRIED? Then this game's got you covered (In more than one way... Grab yer jimmy hats!)It's almost like GTA in some aspects. You can also get a car! (Conditions do apply though; you need money. And parts. And fuel to get the car operating.) But no biggie, once you get that dream car of yours working (And if you've got enough fuel) you should be zooming around the wasteland (Unless an Enclave patrol pulls you over and shoot you with their futuristic-crap weapons. Then you're sunk unless you've got good stats and good armor. Or mutant soldiers, for that matter.) Want to get drunk? There are multiple types of alcoholic drinks that you can (over)indulge in! Feeling really horny? There are sex-workers GALORE. (Though you will be missing the hot pixel-to-pixel action between your hero and the person you're screwing/being screwed by. Too bad. All you get is a black fade-in screen.) Want to be the "cool kid" and take drugs? You won't be doing cocaine or heroine, but try some psycho and jet. Oh, some drugs make you stronger and more intelligent, too (Withdrawl's still a ♥♥♥♥♥.)There are of course, like all other Fallout games, the infamous SPECIAL and karma system. Do you want to be a hero and save the wasteland from evil? Or do you want to join the evils of the wasteland and become infamous? Take your pick, because once you get outta your small podunk settlement, guaranteed, your karma won't be staying at 0. Oh, as for your SPECIAL system, you get a few options: Play with whatever characters the game provides you with (And with their original stats) or just choose that character and modify their stats a wee bit. (Side note, having low intelligence is pretty funny, but on the long run, it will make everything just harder. Take your pick: Funny dialogue, or practical gameplay. Funny dialogue, or practical gameplay.) One thing did kinda get me a bit iffy about the game, though. It's the infamous talking heads. They're hideous. They're... Rather too smooth-looking, some of them. Almost as if they're made from clay. But other than that, that's pretty much it. Other than those hellspawn wanamingoes. Those you try to avoid.Yes, there were glitches (obviously not going to be really patched anytime soon), yes, there were frustrating moments in which I forgot to save and was pushed back 4 quests back (losing massive progress and possibly my laptop due to the amount of frustration), but hell, if you know when to save, know what you're clicking (ESPECIALLY the dialogues, mind you, a wrong click can seriously cause big problems. And you can't back away from it unless you exit and load your closest save), know how to read (And if your character has the intelligence to actually say fluent sentences, but it's rather hilarious and frustrating if your character's intelligence is below 3), you wouldn't regret buying this game. Chock-full of quests, interesting characters, jokes, and random encounters with enemies, friends or foe (the special ones are more or less what we'd call now, "easter eggs") Oh yeah, unlike the original Fallout (Which gives you 150 days on time limit with the waterchip), there really isn't a time limit for this one. I myself took at least over a year screwing around and actually finding the GECK. Though you should still be aware that the game engine itself can only let you play for 13ish in-game years. Do I recommend this game?♥♥♥♥ yes. Is it worth $9.99?Ehhh.... I'd say wait for a sale to happen. I've got my collection at a 75% off sale, and I don't regret that decision one bit.

Posted: January 21
												What can be said about this game? Hmm. Well the first thing you should know is that you shouldn't judge this game by its graphics. The post apocalyptic world many of the modern day gamers are used to seeing is rendered in 3D and significantly different in both story and atmosphere. This world seems almost filthy and bland by comparison.But that's the trick of the matter. This game decieves you thinking its some lame top down RPG when it is actually one of the most immersive games *ever made*In Fallout 2 your character creation really, really, matters. The way you design every stat and trait has ramifications that will help or hinder you throughout the game. People in the world really notice, and not in a stupid skyrim "I see you're a fair hand with a blade" generic line noticing either. You'll converse with them and they'll immediately notice if you are a dumb hulking brute or a sly sneaky sort. If you are handsome or ugly people will comment on it. Hookers will upcharge you if you are too ugly or simple. Murder or hurt enough people and the world hears about it, townspeople will run from you when you walk by, while criminals will nod respectfully as you pass. The way you make and play your character changes everything.Lets just start with Intelligence. If your character is of average intelligence, you can proceed through most of the game normally. But should you have high intelligence many options open up when dealing with more intellectual people or subjects. You can figure out solutions to problems that a less intelligent character couldn't, to the point where some boss fights or enemies can be defeated with a simple dialog option because your character was smart enough to see through the problem.The same goes for charisma. A charismatic character will be able to talk his way out of incredible situations. Heck, if you are persuasive enough you can sleep with a mob boss's wife and convince him you were just lost. You know, just lost, in her bedroom. There are places where you can talk down suicidal bombers or convince hard hearted racists against ghouls to change their ways and be more accepting.Every single stat is like this. Stronger characters will be able to open doors and force their way through situations others can't. More perceptive characters will see hidden traps and doors to avoid enemies and change the way confrontations happen. Every type of character made will have unique ways to solve any problem and this feels *so* good. Maybe you want to be a big stupid brute who is barely smart enough to speak but can kill anything with ease. Maybe you want to be the cocky sharpshooter who is perceptive, smart, and good with a gun but can't take much of a hit. Maybe you want to be completely crazy and give yourself 10 luck and the jinked perk so everyone around you dies in horrible catastrophic accidents while you walk away from huge explosions with minor cuts and scratches.You can do all of these things. The limit is really your imagination. This game is massive in scope and provides hundreds of hours of content, and with the addition of bugfixes and additional content added from the folks at http://killap.net/ who headed the Fallout Restoration Project, it becomes near a thousand hours of things to do in this game.If you want a game that you can play a hundred times and come back a hundred and one times and STILL see something new, buy fallout 2. Its a fabulous product and my only regret is that Bethesda did not put as much care and love into future releases as this original team did into making this a work of beauty, despite its flawed exterior.

Posted: July 13, 2015
												A fantastic sequel to an already amazing game. Took the franchise to a whole new level.+ Maintains the amazing atmosphere Fallout 1 already set up+ Introduces a new and extremely dangerous foe, the Enclave+ Although the game takes place around the same area, the map has expanded around it. You even get to return to Vault 13!+ New enemies and weapons+ Very interesting characters, such as Harold, who is growing a tree out of his freaking head+ Better followers, in which you can control who to fight, when to fight, and how to fight+ Uses the same "Build Up" story that Fallout 1 used. Instead of a water chip, you have to get a G.E.C.K., a device that can save your village from destruction. Seems like a big fetch quest, but like Fallout 1, it turns into something bigger+ Many new locations to go to+ Actually explains why the events of Fallout 1 happened in the first place, and why you had to go and find a water chip+ Combat is for the most part, satisfying. It may get repetitive sometimes, especially if your in power armor running into little Golden Geckos, but when you defeat a squad of the Enclave, it is very satisfactory+ Cities have more of a 40s-50s vibe than Fallout 1+ Again, a few different endings depending on your choices+ Explains what happened to the Vault Dweller after Fallout 1+ SO MANY THINGS TO DO! Become a slaver, get a car and travel the wasteland, save a community of ghouls and men from being killed by a man looking for his son, join the Mafia, buy everyone at the bar a round on the house, get taught how to fight hand to hand by a random guy, save a man's buisness by fixing his moonshine, beat up redneck twins, be a fighting champion, play Mortal Kombat in Chinatown, go on guard duty for 6 hours, and become...+/- Follower AI is a bit wonky, but is usually due to the default settings of the combat controller+/- Not much of a graphical improvement- Enclave can tear you apart at the start- The story is so unclear on what you must do. This is more apparent in this rather than Fallout 1. How was I supposed to know I was suppose to go to Reno, talk to the guy behind the locked door, ask him for a key, wait 1.34186 years exactly so he will say yes, take the key, open up th....10/10 A MasterpieceThis game is a legend in the RPG franchise. The storytelling is awesome, the writing was cheesy at times, but self aware and still great. Bursting with content and a great story to be told with lore to back it up as well. Don't feel bad for looking up guides or anything, as you may absolutely HAVE to in order progress.

												Like so many others fans of the Fallout series, Fallout 1 and 2 have a special place in my heart. I've started by playing Fallout 3 (which at the time mind blew me, but in retrospect... meh), where a friend of mine recommended FO2. I tried it and was hooked. The whole world, the characters, the way it was turn-based... I just loved it. The game has a lot of in it, with plenty of options for completing the game, different way to handle situations, combined with a good sense of humour. Now, this game isn't perfect. It can be buggy as h*ll, especially without the Killap mod(s). That's why my steam account says I have only clocked 8 minutes of the game, because I use the mod instead, which I haven't added to my steam library.The humour, although a strengt for the most parts, can also be weakness. Sometimes the game became a bit too silly and over the top. The game has the tag line "A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game", which it's of course is, but compared to FO1, it sacrificed some of the grimness that the orginal game had.That being said, I think this here is a terrific game, I've glad I tried back then. This game is without a doubt my favorite game of the series and perhaps my favorite game of all times. I know I started playing the game a lot than it came out (10 years in fact), but I think that just prove how good it was, that even after all these years, it still felt innovative and original to a completely new player.I'm sorry I just wrote the review now, since I like the game so much, but since the Steam Awards are coming up, I'm going to bash 2 flies with one swat. I recommend this game for the "TEST OF TIME" award.

Posted: September 18, 2015
												Perfection at its finest. I have no negatives for this game. If you have never played Fallout, Fallout 2, or Fallout tactics and are trying this out after trying Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas, I offer these points.- The game is not first person, it uses a bird eyes view for the gameplay- Nothing is off limits, for example; in FO3 and FNV, killing children was prohibited. Fallout 2 allows you be the biggest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the world. Kill children, desecrate graves, procreate with different women/men, become a slaver, sell off your companions as slaves, and be the biggest a-hole you want to- The speech skills definitely comes in handy more often in Fallout 2. - Fallout 2 has a very dark sense of humor incorporated into it. Fallout 3 is a little happier.Fallout 2 is one of my favorite games of all time. If your a fan of 3 and New Vegas, give this a shot. Just remember its an older game, and will not compare graphic wise. It has an excellent story behind it and plenty of side quests and items that allow you to immerse yourself into the Fallout world.

Posted: October 4, 2015
												Fallout 2 may not look like much at first glance, but it is among my top 3 best games I've ever played in my entire life. The game offers compelling quests and missions that can be performed in literally any way you can imagine, and as you go deeper into the story and explore the different towns and cities, you begin to realize just how well connected everything is. The world feels very much alive and reacts to your decisions in ways that feel significant and reasonable. More importantly, you can become a lot of different things from a grave digger, to a prize fighter, to becoming a reknown pornstar and much more. You can charm your way into people's hearts and influence them to follow you, only to grow tired or bored of them and sell them into slavery. The first 20 minutes can be decieving, get through the tutorial (which can be a little annoying, I know) and you won't regret buying this game.

												First of all, buy this game. Right now. It's an amazing turn-based game and in my opinion an equal to fallout 3 and New Vegas. Now that I have the review done, it's story time.Started up the game, and I'm immediately presented with an intro quest; Make your way through the temple of trials. Simple enough, I set off into the temple and begin my journey. Now, I had built my character for heavy melee combat, so I was easily oneshotting most enemies in the temple. I lockpicked one door and walked through the first part of the temple victorious. The next corridor presented a similar door-based challenge, except now you have to blow the door to bits instead of picking the lock. I wander around, searching for explosives, killing ants, and the norm. After a small while I found a packet of plastic explosives in a container. With my new bomb, I walked up to the previously insurmountable door, place the explosive with a timer for 30 seconds, and hide behind a wall. Now, the bomb has no visible indicator for when it will explode, you just have to wait. So I did. For 20 seconds. I then decided to look at the bomb to see if it had a timer on it, so I click it. However, instead of peeking at the bomb, my character RUNS UP AND GRABS THE LIVE EXPLOSIVE. I panic, try to reset the timer, and subsequently get blown to pieces by my own bomb. 10/10 would suicide bomb a door again.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Basically Fallout with the "Bigger = Better" mindset applied to it. Whether it indeed is better is up for debate, but in my case I'm going to have to fully agree with the side that says it is, because in terms of content this game blows Fallout 1 out of the water. Although lacking an equally intriguing antagonist, Fallout 2 further builds on the greatness of Fallout 1 and increases the world map at least 3 times, adds many new weapons and perks, adds a fully functional companion management system and more. With a bunch of interesting quests, NPCs/companions and locations this game will keep you going for at least 40 hours the first time through. The first time I completed this game and watched the final cutscene I was left in absolute awe, reminiscing about my adventure-filled journey. What an absolute gem of an RPG that anyone hungry for one should get their hands on.If you can't get into the "dated" gameplay (read, "if you are severely lacking taste") then I can only feel bad for what you're missing out on.On a side note, play it with the Restoration Project, it's seriously worth it.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												Like it's predecessor, "Fallout 2" is a classic game. That is to say, it comes from a time where men were real men, women were real women, and real, fuzzy things from Alpha Centauri were real, fuzzy things from Alpha Centauri.My apologies to Douglas Adams.What I mean is that the experience is born of a time when games demanded a lot from players, and pretty much refused to engage in hand-holding. If your character isn't especially scientific, or stealthy, or good at talking, then you'd better be able to independently figure out combat - or you're out of luck. (A well-rounded character may not be your best bet in this game. That was my approach, but I have a sneaky suspicion that the game is much more rewarding for players who choose to specialize.)There is one section, very late in the game, which requires you to solve a rather mind-boggling puzzle. If you can't solve it, you can't progress. This isn't like the "Half-Life 2" episodes, where a major design goal was apparently for every player to see the ending. In "Fallout 2," if you can't get through, it's tough cookies.I cheated. Maybe I'm just a simpleton, but I couldn't get through it without help. I have no idea how anyone figured it out to write the walkthrough, to be frank. (Maybe if I had spend a few hours making detailed notes...maybe.)Like I said: Games like this are demanding, and do not "suffer fools gladly."And if you want to know how this kind of RPG gaming got to where it is now, you need to play this classic title.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												What a wonderful game.  Here are some pro-tips for beginners I wish I'd known at the start:1)  In the first dungeon, the Temple of Trials, you're going to be forced to melee.  Everything in here (ants and scorpions) can be kited if you have at least 7 action points.  Punch something (using 3), and move 4 spaces away from it.  It will use all of its action points to close the 4 space gap, and not be able to attack you.  This will save you a lot of trouble.2)  You can heal yourself using doctor/first aid skills in addition to the powder.  This can only be done successfully three times each though.  (Save your antidotes if poisoned, you'll be able to cure the poison with the use of these skills and/or it will wear off over the course of the time it takes you to attempt to use them)3)  When you enter the second area, walk slowly forward, one space at a time.  As you notice the raised stone plates, use the traps skill on them.  Even if you skill is low, keep using it.  Eventually, you'll disarm them, for 25 XP each.4)  You can steal the key from the final guy to avoid fighting him.  You can keep reloading if your steal skill is low.  Alternatively you can talk him out of the fight if you have enough speech skill.5)  If you level up in the dungeon, don't put points into melee or unarmed. There's a trainer for each in the first village.  If you have less than 55% unarmed skill, you can train to 55%.  There's a guy for melee weapons too, that'll give you +10%.  I'm not sure what the cutoff is.

												Hey, a Fallout game! The first one was fun, and since I've beat all of them but 2, this'll be a piece of cake, right?No. No it will not. This game will murder you over and over and over and over again. If you don't make every choice right this game will rip your arm off an beat you with it, you will know this game inside and out, be able to redraw the map like it was tattooed into your brain. This game is hard to say the least, but is also fun.Pros: Don't get me wrong when I say fun, it's kind of like mowing the lawn for the first time, exciting and you can't wait to do more, but constantly worrying that you'll do it wrong and it'll come back to bite you in the future. Story wise, fantastic. Better than all the others and than some. Also lots of crazy easter eggs and references so be prepared.Cons: Sometimes the game just decides to kill itself and have seizures, but it was made in the 1990's so I'll forgive it.Final thoughts: If you consider yourself a fan of the Fallout series you have to play this. And you should. But if you're asking yourself "I thought Fallout 3 was the first fallout game" or, "why are you stuck in 3rd person", than you should probably stick to COD.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												If you are playing this game because you want a cool open world adventure with lots of freedom and choice this game is for you. Just to give you an idea you can become a pornstar, or you can complete the whole game with an intelligence of 1 and just grunt and make noises in all conversations.If you are expecting to come into the wasteland and pretty much destroy everything that walks in your path at the start like in fallout 3 or NV you will find yourself killed very quickly. You will most likely find yourself running from most enemies at the start of the game because you don't even get a gun, ya you need to find one yourself because guns are very expensive in shops in this game. This makes it all the more satisfying when you actually get your first armor and gun and you slowly are able to take on raiders, golden geckos, and radscorpions. You feel yourself becoming stronger with each new item and level.Your SPECIAL and tag skills mean more in this than 3 and NV as they affect dialogue and combat more, since it is all turn based stats matter more in this game.I love this game it's a big open world with easter eggs to explore and fun sidequest. You really can make your own story which is what makes this game great. Whether you want to be a heartless slaver, a champion boxer, a mafia member, or just a guy who wants to do good in the wasteland it's all available to you. Don't let the age of the game stop you from playing. It's different from 3 or NV, which I still still think are great games, but just like every fallout game it's extremely fun (except brotherhood of steel but I think it's better for everyone to forget that game)

Posted: September 30, 2014
												[Note: The game time logged on Steam does not reflect the time I spent playing Fallout to date. I bought it back in 1997 on CD-ROM and have owned a couple of other bundles which included it since, and have completed Fallout 2 at least a dozen of times since first release.]This is definitely a worthy successor to the first game.  It's bigger, better and it follows the original story line of the "lone wanderer." You're in search for the G.E.C.K., thar Garden Of Eden Creation Kit to save your village.The recipe is the same as in Fallout 1, just improved. It's one of the best RPGs I've played and it thankfully gives you a different setting than the typical fantasy, elven and dwarf infested dungeons. Not that I have anything against that, but this is refreshing!In addition, there is the community developed "Fallout 2 Restoration Project" which adds A LOT of content, fixes and tweaks to the game, that were never added properly, were buggy, or missing. Even if you have completed this game a number of times before (I would hope at least once!), then this adds a tremendous replay value.The cast members of the previous game resume their high quality performances again and all I can say is: Go play. For the love of the lone wanderer, play this game!

Posted: December 29, 2015
												At the very beginning, I had a hard time getting used to the gameplay. Older, openworld games are not something I've played a lot of. (I shy away from largely nonlinear games in general) Despite my overwhleming rejection of the first part of this game, the moment the "tutorial" (if you can call it that) was over I could not put it down. I'm sitting here at 3:30am writing this review and all I've done today is play this game. It's all I've done for the past THREE days. I honestly don't think I've ever been so thouroghly addicted to a game before. It's tense, humurous, intriguing. Also, I chose brains over brawn (Chista) and all of the dialouge choices and sneaky ways to solve things that come with it are really fun to explore and exploit. It didn't feel just like a list of choices or a puzzel on how to chose the right dialouge choice, it was more a question of how what sort of person you wanted to be and added to how you wanted to aproach a variety of groups and people. Fallout 2 has opened my eyes to a new genre of gaming and I highly suggest it to both those who know and love this style of game and those who are a bit iffy about it.Also, don't give up until the "tutorial" stage is over!

Posted: January 26, 2015
												I started with Fallout 3. I'm not ashamed or anything this game came out before I even knew how to play video games. I still love Fallout 3 and the world Bethesda crafted for it. I've replayed it so much I know it like the back of my hand. Obviously being that there was a number 3 at the end of the title it got in my head to wonder "What were the past games like? Fallout 3 has introduced me to a fantastic world and I want to see where it started!" Opun looking at screenshots I remember thinking "Wow... these games look old and crappy". However as time went on I actually played Half Life 1 for the first time which really open my naive eyes to the idea that "Hey! Just because it's old looking doesn't mean it sucks!" So I looked the games up again and decided on getting Fallout 2 over 1 as it said there was no time limit to 2. I can now say that I think Fallout 2 (and 1 respectively) is a far superiour game to Fallout 3. It's amazing how a game where many of the character sprites look the same and the world it self is clearly just 2D with an isometric view could get me so immersed. Being able to place plastic explosive at the foot of a door, set a timer, then run like hell to watch it explode is just one of many things that made me fall in love with this game. While the gore and graphics of Fallout 3 are awesome being in a gunfight with raiders in Fallout 2 is even cooler. I've had a raider aim for my head only to miss and hit the other raider coming up behind me. Fallout 2 is one of the few games that truly made me feel like a Wastleland Vigilante, like Mad Max and Clint Eastwood in one person. I did a mission for a town where I inspected a haunted farm only to find it inhabited by friendly ghouls. When I came back to the town the mayor told me if I didn't find one of their townfolks who had gone missing at the farm they would kill all the ghouls. When I couldn't find him I came back only to find that the mayor had really done it. He really killed all those innocents. So I shot him. I've never been so♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at a fictional character in my life but unlike in a book or a movie I actually got to decide his fate and I decided his time was up.My hope is that Fallout 4 will look back at some of these games and really try to implement some of the amazing player freedoms that this game allowed. If Fallout 4 ended up being and amazing 3d representation of this game my life would complete.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												What a wonderful game.  Here are some pro-tips for beginners I wish I'd known at the start:1)  In the first dungeon, the Temple of Trials, you're going to be forced to melee.  Everything in here (ants and scorpions) can be kited if you have at least 7 action points.  Punch something (using 3), and move 4 spaces away from it.  It will use all of its action points to close the 4 space gap, and not be able to attack you.  This will save you a lot of trouble.2)  You can heal yourself using doctor/first aid skills in addition to the powder.  This can only be done successfully three times each though.  (Save your antidotes if poisoned, you'll be able to cure the poison with the use of these skills and/or it will wear off over the course of the time it takes you to attempt to use them)3)  When you enter the second area, walk slowly forward, one space at a time.  As you notice the raised stone plates, use the traps skill on them.  Even if you skill is low, keep using it.  Eventually, you'll disarm them, for 25 XP each.4)  You can steal the key from the final guy to avoid fighting him.  You can keep reloading if your steal skill is low.  Alternatively you can talk him out of the fight if you have enough speech skill.5)  If you level up in the dungeon, don't put points into melee or unarmed. There's a trainer for each in the first village.  If you have less than 55% unarmed skill, you can train to 55%.  There's a guy for melee weapons too, that'll give you +10%.  I'm not sure what the cutoff is.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												I have to admit that I never played either of the original Fallout games back when they first came out and only became aware of the series during the release of Fallout 3 which I fell in love with. To say I was hesitant in getting into an older game that is known for being arduously difficult and based on the GURPS RPG system is a gods damned understatement. But when that good ol' Steam Holiday sale rolled by and saw this game for the dirt cheap, I decided "What the ♥♥♥♥" and started my new favorite game.Folks without a doubt this is a great game. Its fun, its got great writing, the gameplay mechanics (though challenging at first if unfamiliar) are great, the character system is great...the game is ♥♥♥♥ing great. Obviously, however, it's not perfect. For starters its graphics have aged with the grace of an avacado left under a UV lamp in high humidity for several decades and can prove to be frustrating when you initially start the game and everything looks horribly glitched until you find a fix it. Pacing can be hard to get into if you go from a fast paced pick up and play game, and there is a lot of reading (which isn't a negative but for extensive gaming it can ware your eyes sore).While it is true that you can basically make a perfect character based on how you want to play the game (ex. a character perfect for the main campaign invest stats in X,X,X an X etc.,) the fun of this game is just seeing what happens when you try and not be conventional. This is where the GURPS mechanic shines and as a result I'm looking into the table top game system  . This game is fun to play around in and while, yes trial and error results in several (and I mean SEVERAL) in game deaths for the uninitiated, it helps you get a strong feel for the world you are playing in.Another minor gripe I have is that there is no tutorial, you are basically dropped into the game and left to figure it out, which for some is great, but it would have been nice to have the option.

												90%The missiles were launched. The bombs were dropped. The War happened. Specific details have grown blurry over the last few generations. Scattered, struggling survivors do not keep histories so well. Besides, useless facts about the Ancient Tribes and their politics will not put food on the table or uncontaminated water in the tanks. Do you think the last remaining dinosaurs sat around discussing the color and shape of the comet that doomed them?Some surface dwellers survived, but few without genetic scars from the fallout. Others survived underground, although they too changed in their way. A lucky few lived in the Vaults, built in preparation by the Ancient Tribes. They worked and grew and had children untouched and separated from the holocaust above. But nothing lasts forever, and eventually a reason would make it necessary to leave the Vault and discover what was left of the world. Or sometimes it was the savage outer world that discovered the Vault first. Either way, the Vault dwellers were seldom prepared.This is the world to which you are born, the world of Fallout 2 from Interplay. Your tribe, the Arroyo, are the descendents of survivors from Vault 13 who moved to the surface in the original Fallout. Recently in your village, water is becoming more scarce, raiders more frequent, and the crops are getting thinner and sicker every year.You have been chosen (you lucky dog) to leave the tribe and risk life and limb in search of an ancient artifact. Tribal lore describes the Garden of Eden Creation Kit (GECK) which can be used to build a paradise* (*results may vary). So off you go, bold adventurer, to brave the wastelands, to confront bandits and mutants, to comb the boneyards of the destroyed cities in search of mythical science. At least you have a spear…And you'll need it if you want to make it through the dark, complex, dangerous, intelligent story of Fallout 2. Having last reviewed Zelda 64, it was a bit of a shock moving to Fallout. Unlike the cutsie-poo Zelda, this is a very adult game with complex dynamic plots, a fairly high violence level, a dark mood, and every swear word in the book.In fact, it is difficult if not impossible to be completely moral in this game. Decisions are complex and there are often no right answers. Which New Reno crime syndicate do you help? They're all just competing for the distribution of highly addictive 'jet'. Which competing towns do you help or hinder? Sometimes there are no 'right'anwers.Of course, this assumes you want to try to do right. You can also slaughter the innocent, pimp your wife, and shoot children in the head if that is more to your taste. However, if you do the latter, be prepared to defend yourself from the other townspeople.To be fully prepared, you will need plenty of armor, weapons and ammo. You may begin with only a spear, but there are many levels of technology out there, and you'll quickly move to guns and advanced armor of you wish to survive. There's even power armor and energy weapons when you get far enough.To augment all this, you have seven primary stats and dozens of different skills, abilities and 'perks'. These affect many gameplay issues, not just combat like most other games. I made a fighter for my first character, and lowered his intelligence in order to have plenty of strength. However, I lowered it too much and I soon realized that the computer controlled people were treating me like an idiot (which I was). It was especially frustrating trying to respond to them."I have a job for you, dullard, if you think you can help guard this merchant caravan, " someone might say to me. However, my choice of responses was often limited to "Me Baldric." or "Ug herg ba?"I quickly started a new character. What I am saying here is that the depth of Fallout 2 is simply phenomenal.The graphics, on the other hand, are a bit disappointing. 2D sprites wander about using what is obviously the old Fallout 1 engine. Everything is well detailed, but there aren't very many frames of animation and all the humans tend to look the same. The similar isometric graphics in Ultima Online, for example, have much more character differentiation, and Fallout has no online component at all.The interface is a bit awkward. By making everything 100% mouse driven (there are keyboard shortcuts), they have made many actions difficult. Nothing is impossible (except removing weapons or armor from one of your party members for some reason), but the interface really could have been much more streamlined.Despite these problems, Fallout 2 is highly addictive. The warm, fuzzy, post-apocalyptic world has all the little details and exactly the right tone. The immersive story has kept me up until the wee hours of the morn on many occasions. And finally, if you aren't convinced to buy it yet, Fallout 2 simply has the best opening movie of any game, ever. Now if only I had a telepathic dog and a disposable girlfriend…

												This game is not like any other fallout game to date. Though it's built in an isometric world instead of an FPS, you are immediately immersed into a sprawling universe that feels like it has been existing for a long time now. It doesn't feel like it's built for you to play in, but it was built by it's own citizens. The game is hard. Like, almost near impossible even at a low difficulty setting. This makes conservation of ammo and healing items ESSENTIAL for your surivival, if not totally dependent on it. There are tons of mad max refferences, a car you can drive, and some unique sidequests that you won't see in ANY OTHER fallout games.Before you start playing, get into the habit of saving after every encounter with an enemy. A large amount of uncontrollable variables can get you or your team killed in an instant. I'd give this a 9/10, the games only flaw  (for me)  being the incredible difficulty.

												Fallout 1 was a very good game.. but this one probably takes the crown. Even though Fallout 3 and New Vegas are very very good games.. this one still has to be my favorite.. for its time. This game really did good for its time, the random encounters are pretty fun so many unique and interesting things to run into, there is SO much to do. I never get bored of this game, I still play it even now. Plus it brings back so many good memories. I'd recommend this game to anyone who loves RPGs, if you liked Diablo it's a chance you may like this game.. if you liked Final fantasy, there's also a good chance you'll like it. It is a turned based combat system. But it's been developed smart and it's very fun and helpful if you love strategy games. Also if you liked X-Com.. you may fall in love with Fallout 2. Posted: April 24, 2015
												What a wonderful game.  Here are some pro-tips for beginners I wish I'd known at the start:1)  In the first dungeon, the Temple of Trials, you're going to be forced to melee.  Everything in here (ants and scorpions) can be kited if you have at least 7 action points.  Punch something (using 3), and move 4 spaces away from it.  It will use all of its action points to close the 4 space gap, and not be able to attack you.  This will save you a lot of trouble.2)  You can heal yourself using doctor/first aid skills in addition to the powder.  This can only be done successfully three times each though.  (Save your antidotes if poisoned, you'll be able to cure the poison with the use of these skills and/or it will wear off over the course of the time it takes you to attempt to use them)3)  When you enter the second area, walk slowly forward, one space at a time.  As you notice the raised stone plates, use the traps skill on them.  Even if you skill is low, keep using it.  Eventually, you'll disarm them, for 25 XP each.4)  You can steal the key from the final guy to avoid fighting him.  You can keep reloading if your steal skill is low.  Alternatively you can talk him out of the fight if you have enough speech skill.5)  If you level up in the dungeon, don't put points into melee or unarmed. There's a trainer for each in the first village.  If you have less than 55% unarmed skill, you can train to 55%.  There's a guy for melee weapons too, that'll give you +10%.  I'm not sure what the cutoff is.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												In the beginning there was Baldurs Gate which you can now buy (enhanced editions 1 & 2 on steam) to re-live the classic RPG/Adventure/D&D style of gameplay...but in the late 90's there was fallout.  It introduced a different kind of tone: a  post-apocalyptic world for you to explore.  Fallout 2 however really expanded in terms of allowing you to really explore and do whatever you want.  There is no right or wrong way to play...and if you beat the game you can still play it afterwards.  On one of my save files I was a hero who tried to do the right thing but eventually became a slave trader/runner.  I would massacre little towns and loot them because I had become so savage and primal.  I tried to redeem myself but I became addicted to Jet and my legs became permanently broken from all the drugs I injested.  I just stayed in New Reno gambling my life away and doing more Jet.  This is a classic gem!  Try it out it even if you've played Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas it does a lot of things that they tried to implement but could not really capture from the original Fallout 2.  P.S. Nothing beats punching a little kid in a town who throws rocks at you with power armor...seeing his body drag along that map brings back memories!!

												One of the best games I've ever played.I recommend playing it with either Killap's Unofficial Patch or Killap's Restoration Project (includes the Patch)Killap's Patch fixes MANY of the bugs in the game.Killap's Restoration Project does everything the Patch does and more, adding most cut content in the game. If you're aiming for the best ending, you technically need this, otherwise you wont get the Vault 13 best ending due to it being cut.Pros+I really like its art style for some reason+Several times larger and content-packed than the original Fallout+Your actions have consequences (in the ending slides)Cons-Bad companion AI. Thankfully you can shove them, but you have to do this several times to get them out of the wayOther:The Restoration Project makes the beginning of the game way more difficult. However, the danger of being killed by a single gecko can be avoided by getting Sulik as a companion ASAP.Perfect choice for the "Test of Time" award, in my opinion.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												In the beginning there was Baldurs Gate which you can now buy (enhanced editions 1 & 2 on steam) to re-live the classic RPG/Adventure/D&D style of gameplay...but in the late 90's there was fallout.  It introduced a different kind of tone: a  post-apocalyptic world for you to explore.  Fallout 2 however really expanded in terms of allowing you to really explore and do whatever you want.  There is no right or wrong way to play...and if you beat the game you can still play it afterwards.  On one of my save files I was a hero who tried to do the right thing but eventually became a slave trader/runner.  I would massacre little towns and loot them because I had become so savage and primal.  I tried to redeem myself but I became addicted to Jet and my legs became permanently broken from all the drugs I injested.  I just stayed in New Reno gambling my life away and doing more Jet.  This is a classic gem!  Try it out it even if you've played Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas it does a lot of things that they tried to implement but could not really capture from the original Fallout 2.  P.S. Nothing beats punching a little kid in a town who throws rocks at you with power armor...seeing his body drag along that map brings back memories!!

Posted: March 30, 2015
												When the original Fallout shipped, it was hailed by many to be the savoir of computer RPGs. With its gritty story, compelling art design, and brilliant mix of old school statistical based combat and an interface easy enough for a beginner to use, the game not only pleased the hard core niche market, but also introduced the joys of role-playing to a whole new generation. Now all the company had to do was to make another one that would make everyone just as happy. With Fallout 2, the company has done just that. Despite the loss of crucial team members, economic difficulties within the company and an irritable consumer base, the development team at Black Isle Studios, Interplay's internal role-playing division, has put together a game that is everything the original was and perhaps, a bit more.Let's bring you up to date. You are the descendant of the original Vault-Dweller who wandered the plains in search of a water chip. As the game starts, you are asked to run a gauntlet that will prove you to be the Chosen One, the one worthy to wear the suit of the Vault-Dweller. Once you complete this relatively easy task, you find out what's really going down. Your village is dying. In a last ditch attempt to save the town, the elder is sending you out into the real world to find a device that has been whispered of in legends called the Garden of Eden Creation Kit (or G.E.C.K.). Sent away from the only home you've ever known, armed only with a spear you must wander into a world filled with mutants, ghouls and raiders in order to save your people.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												If you're a huge fan of the Fallout series, take a gander at this installment...Pros:1)Multiple friendly, humorous and diverse compainions to choose from.2)For it's time, the graphics have intense messaging; you really get the sense that you're one of the few left in the wasteland.3)A challenging plethora of side quest across many towns and settlements.4)(Depending on hardware performance) Smooth and crisp tansitions between areas.5)The only true loading screen you see is at the beginning.Cons:1)Somewhat reduntant encounters and brawls amongst semi-generic enemies.2)Turn based combat leads to a back and forth, stimpack filled feud with the smallest of creatures.3)Even with the inclusion of a "push back" button for NPCs and companions, you'll always find yourself cramped in a large area.4) Dying isn't fun in any game; this game reinforces that statement to a broad point.5)The occasional framerate drop when entering a new area may force you to restart the game.With those points in mind, decide...to walk the wastes...or not, I guess.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												=======================Start 1: Torgue's Apprentice======================Obtain some explosivesArm those explosivesThen let someone to steal them from you (works best in crowded places)Wait for timer to run outObserve results=======================Start 2: Beauty in a tin-can=======================Meet Sergeant Dornan without advanced power armorListen to him while having your speakers\headphones at max volumeGet thy advanced power armorGet laid while wearing advanced power armorBecome a porn star while wearing advanced power armor=======================Start 3: I hate logic=============================Get familiar with jinxed traitThen find unlucky dogGet double jinxedWatch everyone fail miserably at their job=======================Start 4: The stylish thief wasteland==================Max out charisma and agilitySteal everything from everyoneRinse and repeat the second part=======================Start 5: Yough fren?============================Set intelligence to 1 and Charisma to 10 or 1Hngh?Uhhh....On serious note:Start options listed above are just simple and wacky examples of what can be done just by creating character and playing the game. Difficulty is somewhat rng'ish, for example you can meet very tough opponent in certain areas at start of the game but such are the wastes, harsh and unforgiving. Gameplay is a perfect mix of strategy and rpg with rng for a good measure. AI without mods is somewhat dumb, so don't get surprised if it does something wacky.Visual part is something from 1995'ish but still pretty good.Stability is kind of nice, it runs smooth and mostly stable on modern systems although not flawless (might be a few crashes here and there at certain points in the game).Overall it's a great game but not flawless. Thankfully all of the irks and kinks can be fixed by mods.If you were looking for a serious RPG with deep immersion and good story then this game is for you.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												The best rpg I've ever played, bar none. Usually such grand claims for old classics are attributed to the rose tinted glasses of nostalgia, except in my case I totally missedthe game when it first came out, raising my nose at the notion of turn-based rpg combat. What I fool I was! I played Fallout 2 for the first time more than 10 years after its release, long after the likes of rpgs like Diablo 2, Morrowind, Oblivion, Icewind Dale and Neverwinter Nights. And yet Fallout 2 quickly became my favorite.pros: + Incredible atmosphere, due to a believable and very well realized post apocalyptic wasteland     made all the more powerful by the superb soundtrack.+ Robust and diverse character leveling system in which you are spoiled for choice most of the time.     Far less constricted compared to something like Neverwinter Nights.+ Satisfying and brutal combat with excellent sound and visual effects.+ Huge, but manageable world to explore with loads of interesting locations and people to interact with.+ Very good replay value, with multiple ways to complete quests, and some quests being mutually exclusive. Also,    the restoration project adds tons of content which is perfect for a 2nd playthrough.+ Fun easter eggs, of which there are quite a few.cons:- Starts slow and can be a little annoying the first hour or so while you are still dependent on your spear and ammo is sparse (unless you're going for a melee character).- Can get quite difficult.

Posted: November 27, 2015
												Fallout 2 picks up where Fallout essentially left off. More storyline, guns, smart-assness, complete with fresh combat and more tactical options with your party.Steal from kids. Lie about doing it. Then throw a rock at their face for accusing you. Groin punch a porn star after you make bank on her face. Pay another one to do your Hulkified mutant buddy. Make a few robo dogs to go with your real dog(meat)! Cruise around in a 70's style car with a nuclear engine with a big enough trunk to fit every item in the game. Pimp out your gay husband, or face ride girls as a lesbian with a sledge hammer.Drugs? There's drugs, go find the trash talking Erkel to make you a ton before you go on a huge killing spree in a nice quiet town. Then reload so you can play nice, like you totally didn't just shotgun that old lady in front of the guard 2 minutes ago. Give your big mutant buddy a minigun and watch him carelessly take out half your party. Why? Because that Mole Rat has 1HP left, that's why.Now go put on your rubber boots, skin some geckos, find Smiley, and sell your newfound tribal friend to some slavers. Then tell them where your village is and help them round up your people too!Like I said. Tactical. Options.

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Much broader in scope and storyline than was its predecessor. There is much more to see and do in this game. It is a true non-linear game that lets you do pretty much whatever you want. One of the first, open world games. Fallout 2 contains dozens of subtle and more often not-so-subtle references to cult movies, television icons, and other aspects of popular culture. If you value character development, old-fashioned gameplay, and a good plot, this game delivers on all counts.  Has great post-apocalyptic atmosphere, awesome turn-based combat, non-linear playthrough and a variety of gamestyles/ways to solve quests/ways to win batt;es, variety of items/guns/ammo/armor, numerous sidequests, amd memorable NPCs. However, the game suffers from a myriad of bugs in its original form, applying "Killap's Unofficial Fallout 2 Patch" found on killap.net removes most of the bugs and adds a bit of extra content. The game is truly worth the money.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												In case you don't want to read this here is the summary:9.5/10 - A must have game for an RPG fan.In case you are interested in my opinion:Fallout 2 is a great RPG.I recommend playing the first Fallout before it, as there is a lot of overlapping content that you can only appreciate if you have played both games. I first started with games from the 2004 onward, so picking up Fallout was a little difficult.The controls and interface proved problematic at first, but overcoming this challenge provided me with more joy and satisfaction than many "modern"games did.If you can overcome the difficulties posed by the beforementioned things, this game offers you role-playing options that will reward you like no other "modern" RPG can. You just cannot create a jack of all trade character (unlike in Fallout 4) and the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system is not just a gimmick (like in Fallout 4). Conversations have a lot more depth and meaning and you can totally create a character of your own and really play as that character.The game's story is nothing special (huh, get it?) it is quite good, just not Bioshock Infinite good.(it may be infair to compare a game released in 1998 to a game release 15 years later, and probably with 10 times higher budget and way longer developement time)What Black Isle Studios made is truly astonishing IMHO.With Fallout they have created a truly unique universe.With Fallout 2 they have expanded that universe and in a funny yet just as desolate way and that is why so many people love it, including myself.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												Nearly 20 years later and this remains my all-time favorite game. Its "go anywhere you want at any time" approach was something that most of the RPGs of its time were not doing. Sure Baldur's Gate had a big world, but it had a fairly linear path through it. Fallout 2 just set you loose to go wherever you want from the start. The more modern RPGs that share this approach (such as Bethesda's) are great, but they can't match the sheer scale that Fallout 2 had, even with almost 2 decades of advances.

												It may say I've only played this game for 3 hours but believe me. Before Stream I played this game till my PC had a melt down. I've purchased this game more than once as well and its been worth it each time. Everything has already been said about how great this game is so I'll just say my favourite things about this game.Replay value. As I have said that I've played this a lot. Each time I have played it the game is different. I have discovered new places and events each time I have played it. There are millions of way to approach this game. Actions has consequences. You can't just do what ever you want but in the world of Fallout 2 you can do what ever you want. But there are consequences.Anything you do. If you become a porn star there are some Pro's in it but many of the NPC will loss respect for you and make fun of you.Become a slaver? Nice money in it. But you can forget about entering half the towns in the game. Wear power armor that will stop any bullet. Get laughed at for looking like a walking refrigerator.Set off a nuclear explosion and everyone in the fallout 2 world will talk about it.If you set off a nuclear explosion in megaton in fallout 3 nobody bats an eye. Even if you go back to Megaton everyone has turned into gauls NOBODY QUESTIONS IT? What the hell kinda game is Fallout3?You're not forced into anything. Unlike in Fallout 4 where you are forced to help out NPC at the start of the game and be a good sport. There is nothing like that in fallout 2. You can be evil or nice or both. You can kill anyone in the game. even important NPC that are important.Did some little kid just steal from you? What a little♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'm gonna shot him in the groin for that. Can't do that in the newer fallouts. And my favourite thing about Fallout 2 which no other game in the world comes close to this is at the very end when you complete the game you get a prologue of all the towns. Basically you get to see what you actions have done to the Fallout 2 world. Which towns have made a change. Which ones have advanced, which ones failed and died. Very satisfying to see. And it changes each time you play it. Absolutely brilliant Name 6 reasons why fallout 3,4 is better than this game? You can't.

												There is not enough good that can be said about Fallout 2. I played it for thousands of hours growing up and will still play it again. In my opinion, it is the best game every made. It is perfectly balanced, unique, clever, heartwrenching and inspiring. It has covered every base that needs to be in a game and much more. From entirely unique units and scenarios, to challenging and satisfying turn-based combat with splashes of hilarity, Fallout 2 cannot disappoint. With hundreds of easter eggs/references to other games, shows, movies and more, any 80's-90's kid will be in heaven.The game is 18 years old and I will happily replay it against any current-day title. This is the strongest Fallout title of the series and is a must-buy for any RPG, post-apocalyptic scenario, or turn-based enthusiast.

												I have played only about 30 minutes of this game and I was expecting it to be cringy, but I was delightfully suprised by the depth of this game. Posted: January 22, 2016
												After more than 70 hours, I'm finally done with this game... And what can I say about it ? I really really enjoyed it. This game DOES have an atmosphere. You really feel like you are in the wasteland, in this desert 2 centuries after the Great War that brought the end of the world.Plus it's the kind of game where your choices actually matter, and change the way you play. You sometimes will be the one to decide wether you will save a village because you're a good guy, or we will blow it up, like the city of Gecko for example. Same for Vault 13, you can decide to help or... kill the inhabitants, it's up to you.But there's one thing I can blame this game for: it is not well balanced. By this I mean you will sometimes have to face very strong ennemies (especially during random encounters) while you are still low level. But once you get the power armor, you are almost invincible because most ennemies won't even be able to hurt you.So yes, I strongly recommand Fallout 2 even if you may turn crazy because it tends to be kinda hard sometimes. But you will enjoy it because of the combat system and the atmosphere. It's light years away from Fallout 4...

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Much broader in scope and storyline than was its predecessor. There is much more to see and do in this game. It is a true non-linear game that lets you do pretty much whatever you want. One of the first, open world games. Fallout 2 contains dozens of subtle and more often not-so-subtle references to cult movies, television icons, and other aspects of popular culture. If you value character development, old-fashioned gameplay, and a good plot, this game delivers on all counts.  Has great post-apocalyptic atmosphere, awesome turn-based combat, non-linear playthrough and a variety of gamestyles/ways to solve quests/ways to win batt;es, variety of items/guns/ammo/armor, numerous sidequests, amd memorable NPCs. However, the game suffers from a myriad of bugs in its original form, applying "Killap's Unofficial Fallout 2 Patch" found on killap.net removes most of the bugs and adds a bit of extra content. The game is truly worth the money.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												The quintessential post-apocalyptic CRPG, in my humble opinion. Don't take my game time fool you, I've owned the physical CD for years. It just became impractical to not have a digital copy now a days. If you liked and/or loved Fallout 1, you will very much enjoy this sequal. Gameplay wise, it follows the first; turned based combat, open world travel via world map, SPECIAL system, etc. However, the sequel gives a lot more freedom to the player with a larger world, and longer plot line that has you travel all over the place. You don't have to play the first to play the second, as it only loosely makes references to events that occured in the first game. Additionaly the dialouge takes on a more darker tone rarely found in modern RPGS, and does not shy away from letting the player do pretty much anything they want within the boundaries of the gameworld and game engine.Over the years, this game has held up extremely well in my view, and I would often find myself wanting to come back and experience it all over again. If you want to add more content to the game I highly suggest you try out MIBB's Megamod. If you wish to just have content cut from the original game restored, with a few added features, I suggest trying the Fallout 2 Restoration Project.Closing: If you love the post-apocalyptic genre and crpgs, get this game.

Posted: October 29, 2016
												This game is unique and, in my opinion, still holds up to this day if you get used to how it plays. No other game did I genuinely laugh out loud at a conversation that I had with an NPC, and text based, too. This game has some of the best writing you will ever see in any RPG that you have played before, and most importantly, it is addictively fun; not Fallout 4's shoot and loot fun, but more questing and talking fun. Fallout 2 is one of those unique, special games that makes you always think twice about every little decision that you make. The world is fully tailored to your actions, and you rarely decide to kill someone because it can have disasterous concequences on the story or immediate situation. Although almost all of the quests are linear, most of the endings to the quests have some form of choice that lets the outcome fall into your favour (or maybe not, which is the beauty of this game). You truly feel like you're in a post-apocalyptic world; everything in this game is HARD, difficulty wise, and brutal, atmosphere wise.So, do I recommend this game? Yes, but only if you think you have the patience to play it. Combat can be exedingly slow at some times, and the first 2 hours of the story can feel a bit more boring than the rest of the 46 hours playing the game. If you are looking for a hard, gritty game full of choices with a story tailored to you and a very rewarding ending, look no further than Fallout 2.

I first started with games from the 2004 onward, so picking up Fallout was a little difficult.The controls and interface proved problematic at first, but overcoming this challenge provided me with more joy and satisfaction than many "modern"games did.If you can overcome the difficulties posed by the beforementioned things, this game offers you role-playing options that will reward you like no other "modern" RPG can. You just cannot create a jack of all trade character (unlike in Fallout 4) and the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system is not just a gimmick (like in Fallout 4). Conversations have a lot more depth and meaning and you can totally create a character of your own and really play as that character.The game's story is nothing special (huh, get it?) it is quite good, just not Bioshock Infinite good.(it may be infair to compare a game released in 1998 to a game release 15 years later, and probably with 10 times higher budget and way longer developement time)What Black Isle Studios made is truly astonishing IMHO.With Fallout they have created a truly unique universe.With Fallout 2 they have expanded that universe and in a funny yet just as desolate way and that is why so many people love it, including myself.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												My test of time nomination was a no brainer for me. I don't know how many copies of this game I've collected over the years, physical and digital. I've picked it up again here purely so I can gush about it.The best RPG's, I find, are the ones where the story shapes the character as you play, and vice versa. Not unlike a tabletop RPG, where a good DM can contextualise and personalise the game as it goes. I love it when I go in with a vague idea, maybe thinking about certain skills to focus in, and the further I go the more personality they come to have, developed all on their own, unexpected and unplanned. Before long dialogue choices become easy, because that's what the character would say. This is one of the earliest and best examples of games I've played that have enabled this experience for me.Also, the fact I could flirt with female characters while playing a female character, and even marry one (joke though it was) blew my tiny teenage lesbian mind.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												There is not enough good that can be said about Fallout 2. I played it for thousands of hours growing up and will still play it again. In my opinion, it is the best game every made. It is perfectly balanced, unique, clever, heartwrenching and inspiring. It has covered every base that needs to be in a game and much more. From entirely unique units and scenarios, to challenging and satisfying turn-based combat with splashes of hilarity, Fallout 2 cannot disappoint. With hundreds of easter eggs/references to other games, shows, movies and more, any 80's-90's kid will be in heaven.The game is 18 years old and I will happily replay it against any current-day title. This is the strongest Fallout title of the series and is a must-buy for any RPG, post-apocalyptic scenario, or turn-based enthusiast.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Second installement of the classic collection.The gameplay has not changed and is still the same turn-based style like all 3. There are some improvements with the inventory system, you can finally "take all" instead of dragging and dropping each item to your inventory side. There are more weapons, items, enemies and areas of the map to explore which is a plus!The only problem I had were some quest bugs that made them impossible to complete, they'd automatically fail you even though you'd "complete" them which makes it a pain if you want to be a completionist...Other than the few bugs that can break the game's quests, this game is still a classic and always fun to pick up and play if you enjoyed the previous title.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												To this very day Fallout 2 is one of the best games that I've ever laid hands on. I played it back in school for hundreds of hours and now that you can get it on Steam, I just had to buy it once more. Its graphics might seem quite outdated, but if you're not too much of a superficial gamer, you should be able to deal with it.What makes this game so incredibly beautiful is the developers' love for details and a really convincing atmosphere. You get thrown into a post-apocalyptic world full of glorious black humour, knowing only little about your actual main quest. There is barely any hand-holding, which modern RPGs do all too much. In Fallout 2 there are no quest markers, only hints. To solve your missions, you have to listen to what NPCs tell you, instead of clicking right through dialogues, following a pointer on your minimap and shooting a few bandits in the face. As most things in Fallout 2 can be done in a variety of ways, you can solve problems by talking, violence, in favor of your own interests or to help a certain person or faction. And the outcome will always be entirely different. You decide everything.On your way through the radioactive desert of the American West Coast you will discover tons of secrets, interesting characters, quests and enthralling side stories. Considering its release date, the game's actually huge. I've played Fallout an infinite number of times, but so far I always managed to discover something new - be it a secret area, a new way to solve a certain quest or just another crazy NPC.As if this wasn't enough cool things to know about Fallout 2 already, there's even more. For example Fallout's unique character creation system. Your avatar will have a truckload of skills, talents, perks and attributes, which have a direct influence on the gameplay and everything else. You want to conquer the wasteland as a highly intelligent scientist and sweet-talker instead of being a violent brute? Want to be a sniper instead of chopping your enemies with a chainsaw knife? Well, just give it a shot. No two playthroughs will ever be the same.I could go on and worship this game for another 20 minutes, but I think, if you're not convinced by now, you won't ever be. However, if you're into oldschool RPGS, buy this game and experience one of the most superior titles in video gaming history. Period.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												At the very beginning, I had a hard time getting used to the gameplay. Older, openworld games are not something I've played a lot of. (I shy away from largely nonlinear games in general) Despite my overwhleming rejection of the first part of this game, the moment the "tutorial" (if you can call it that) was over I could not put it down. I'm sitting here at 3:30am writing this review and all I've done today is play this game. It's all I've done for the past THREE days. I honestly don't think I've ever been so thouroghly addicted to a game before. It's tense, humurous, intriguing. Also, I chose brains over brawn (Chista) and all of the dialouge choices and sneaky ways to solve things that come with it are really fun to explore and exploit. It didn't feel just like a list of choices or a puzzel on how to chose the right dialouge choice, it was more a question of how what sort of person you wanted to be and added to how you wanted to aproach a variety of groups and people. Fallout 2 has opened my eyes to a new genre of gaming and I highly suggest it to both those who know and love this style of game and those who are a bit iffy about it.Also, don't give up until the "tutorial" stage is over!

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Look, I'll be honest this game is definitly not for everyone. It has a steep learning curve, no waypoints to tell you where to go, and no ♥♥♥♥ing autosaves. Jesus Christ I had to restart atleast five different times because I forgot to save. However this game can also be one of the most immersive and enjoyable RPG experiences you will ever encounter if you let it. I made three characters who played basicly the same (Mr. Generic man who always did the "right thing" and shot guns) and got three distinct ending. This game is great at making sure your actions matter, like in this one quest where you have to find this drunken ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ somewhere in the wastes within 30 days or one group of survivors will be slaughtered. Also the companions, they were a true step up from the companions of fallout 1 and in some ways better than the ones in the more modern Fallout titles by Bethesda Softworks. Most were fully voice acted with few exceptions, and they were really believable and it in many cases it was very emotional when they died. It also presented you with a tough choice of wether to continue on with your adventure and know they will never come back or reload an earlier save to prevent this frome happening but lose your progress and maybe some sweet gear in the process. Now if you do consider getting this game I strongly recomend getting the Killapp Fallout 2 restoration project. This fixes most of the bugs and glitches with this game and also adds stuff that was intended to be in the game but was never added because it was rushed. The instalation is quite simple, and is fully explained on his website. Now it should be stated that you do not need to play the first game to understand what is going on partially because this game takes place 80 years after the first one and the events of the first game are explained well enough in the begining of the game.  This review is brought to you by Vault-Tec, and sign up at your local vault shelter today!

Posted: January 20, 2015
												=======================Start 1: Torgue's Apprentice======================Obtain some explosivesArm those explosivesThen let someone to steal them from you (works best in crowded places)Wait for timer to run outObserve results=======================Start 2: Beauty in a tin-can=======================Meet Sergeant Dornan without advanced power armorListen to him while having your speakers\headphones at max volumeGet thy advanced power armorGet laid while wearing advanced power armorBecome a porn star while wearing advanced power armor=======================Start 3: I hate logic=============================Get familiar with jinxed traitThen find unlucky dogGet double jinxedWatch everyone fail miserably at their job=======================Start 4: The stylish thief wasteland==================Max out charisma and agilitySteal everything from everyoneRinse and repeat the second part=======================Start 5: Yough fren?============================Set intelligence to 1 and Charisma to 10 or 1Hngh?Uhhh....On serious note:Start options listed above are just simple and wacky examples of what can be done just by creating character and playing the game. Difficulty is somewhat rng'ish, for example you can meet very tough opponent in certain areas at start of the game but such are the wastes, harsh and unforgiving. Gameplay is a perfect mix of strategy and rpg with rng for a good measure. AI without mods is somewhat dumb, so don't get surprised if it does something wacky.Visual part is something from 1995'ish but still pretty good.Stability is kind of nice, it runs smooth and mostly stable on modern systems although not flawless (might be a few crashes here and there at certain points in the game).Overall it's a great game but not flawless. Thankfully all of the irks and kinks can be fixed by mods.If you were looking for a serious RPG with deep immersion and good story then this game is for you.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												At the very beginning, I had a hard time getting used to the gameplay. Older, openworld games are not something I've played a lot of. (I shy away from largely nonlinear games in general) Despite my overwhleming rejection of the first part of this game, the moment the "tutorial" (if you can call it that) was over I could not put it down. I'm sitting here at 3:30am writing this review and all I've done today is play this game. It's all I've done for the past THREE days. I honestly don't think I've ever been so thouroghly addicted to a game before. It's tense, humurous, intriguing. Also, I chose brains over brawn (Chista) and all of the dialouge choices and sneaky ways to solve things that come with it are really fun to explore and exploit. It didn't feel just like a list of choices or a puzzel on how to chose the right dialouge choice, it was more a question of how what sort of person you wanted to be and added to how you wanted to aproach a variety of groups and people. Fallout 2 has opened my eyes to a new genre of gaming and I highly suggest it to both those who know and love this style of game and those who are a bit iffy about it.Also, don't give up until the "tutorial" stage is over!

Posted: November 26, 2016
												My test of time nomination was a no brainer for me. I don't know how many copies of this game I've collected over the years, physical and digital. I've picked it up again here purely so I can gush about it.The best RPG's, I find, are the ones where the story shapes the character as you play, and vice versa. Not unlike a tabletop RPG, where a good DM can contextualise and personalise the game as it goes. I love it when I go in with a vague idea, maybe thinking about certain skills to focus in, and the further I go the more personality they come to have, developed all on their own, unexpected and unplanned. Before long dialogue choices become easy, because that's what the character would say. This is one of the earliest and best examples of games I've played that have enabled this experience for me.Also, the fact I could flirt with female characters while playing a female character, and even marry one (joke though it was) blew my tiny teenage lesbian mind.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												The quintessential post-apocalyptic CRPG, in my humble opinion. Don't take my game time fool you, I've owned the physical CD for years. It just became impractical to not have a digital copy now a days. If you liked and/or loved Fallout 1, you will very much enjoy this sequal. Gameplay wise, it follows the first; turned based combat, open world travel via world map, SPECIAL system, etc. However, the sequel gives a lot more freedom to the player with a larger world, and longer plot line that has you travel all over the place. You don't have to play the first to play the second, as it only loosely makes references to events that occured in the first game. Additionaly the dialouge takes on a more darker tone rarely found in modern RPGS, and does not shy away from letting the player do pretty much anything they want within the boundaries of the gameworld and game engine.Over the years, this game has held up extremely well in my view, and I would often find myself wanting to come back and experience it all over again. If you want to add more content to the game I highly suggest you try out MIBB's Megamod. If you wish to just have content cut from the original game restored, with a few added features, I suggest trying the Fallout 2 Restoration Project.Closing: If you love the post-apocalyptic genre and crpgs, get this game.
